{"uri": "8113993091", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "14:49:21", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T14:49:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T14:48:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/law-order/2929330-trump-fined-1000-for-gag-order-violation-faces-potential-jail-time", "title": "Trump Fined $1,000 for Gag Order Violation, Faces Potential Jail Time | Law-Order", "body": "Trump fined $1,000 for violating gag order, warned of possible jail time. Prosecutors present insider testimony from former aide Hope Hicks in hush money trial. Hicks described Trump's reaction to damaging 2016 recording. Trial continues with expected testimony from former Trump lawyer Michael Cohen. Trump faces 34 felony counts related to hush money payments. Defense seeks to undermine witness credibility and raise extortion allegations.\n\nThe judge presiding over Donald Trump's hush money trial has fined him $1,000 for violating his gag order and sternly warned the former president that additional violation could result in jail time.\n\nThe fine marks the second sanction for Trump for inflammatory comments about witnesses since the start of the trial last month. He was fined $9,000 last week for nine violations.\n\nJudge Juan M Merchan warned Monday that additional gag order violations could potentially result in jail time, though he said that was \"the last thing I want to do\".\n\nProsecutors in Trump's hush money trial are moving deeper into his orbit following an inside-the-room account about the former president's reaction to a politically damaging recording that surfaced in the final weeks of the 2016 campaign.\n\nHope Hicks, a former White House official and for years a top aide, is by far the closest Trump associate to have taken the witness stand in the Manhattan trial.\n\nHer testimony Friday was designed to give jurors an insider's view of a chaotic and pivotal stretch in the campaign, when a 2005 recording showing Trump talking about grabbing women without their permission was made public and when he and his allies sought to prevent the release of other potentially embarrassing stories. That effort, prosecutors say, included hush money payments to a porn actor and Playboy model who both have said they had sexual encounters with Trump before he entered politics.\n\n\"I had a good sense to believe this was going to be a massive story and that it was going to dominate the news cycle for the next several days,\" Hicks said of the \"Access Hollywood\" recording, first revealed in an October 2016 Washington Post story. \"This was a damaging development.\" The trial enters its third week of testimony Monday with prosecutors building toward their star witness, Michael Cohen, Trump's former lawyer and personal fixer who pleaded guilty to federal charges related to the hush money payments. Cohen is expected to undergo a bruising cross-examination from defense attorneys seeking to undermine his credibility with jurors.\n\nTrump faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records in connection with payments made to stifle potentially embarrassing stories. Prosecutors say Trump's company, the Trump Organization, reimbursed Cohen for payments to porn actor Stormy Daniels and gave Cohen bonuses and extra payments. Prosecutors allege that those transactions were falsely logged in company records as legal expenses.\n\nTrump has pleaded not guilty and denied sexual encounters with any of the women, as well as any wrongdoing.\n\nSo far, jurors have heard from witnesses including a tabloid magazine publisher and Trump friend who bought the rights to several sordid tales about Trump to prevent them from coming out and a Los Angeles lawyer who negotiated hush money deals on behalf of both Daniels and Playboy model Karen McDougal.\n\nTrump's lawyers have tried to chip away at the prosecution's theory of the case and the credibility of some witnesses. They've raised questions during cross-examinations about whether Trump was possibly a target of extortion, forced to arrange payouts to suppress harmful stories and spare his family embarrassment and pain. Prosecutors maintain the payments were about preserving his political viability as he sought the presidency.\n\nThe case is one of four Trump prosecutions and possibly the only one that will reach trial before the November election. Other felony indictments charge him with plotting to subvert the 2020 presidential election after he lost to Democrat Joe Biden and illegally hoarding classified documents after he left the White House.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Devdiscourse"}, {"uri": "2024-05-346581428", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "14:06:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T14:06:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T14:06:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.yorkpress.co.uk/news/national/24301593.trump-fined-gag-order-violation-hush-money-case/", "title": "Trump fined again over gag order violation in hush money case", "body": "The judge presiding over Donald Trump's hush money trial has fined him 1,000 dollars (nearly \u00a3800) for violating his gag order - and sternly warned the former president that additional violation could result in jail time.\n\nThe fine marks the second sanction for Trump for inflammatory comments about witnesses since the start of the trial last month. He was fined 9,000 dollars (\u00a37,172) last week for nine violations.\n\nJudge Juan M Merchan warned Trump on Monday that additional gag order violations could potentially result in jail time, though he said that was \"the last thing I want to do\".\n\nProsecutors in Trump's hush money trial are moving deeper into his orbit following an inside-the-room account about the former president's reaction to a politically damaging recording that surfaced in the final weeks of the 2016 campaign.\n\nHope Hicks, a former White House official and for years a top aide, is by far the closest Trump associate to have given evidence in the Manhattan trial.\n\nHer testimony on Friday was designed to give jurors an insider's view of a chaotic and pivotal stretch in the campaign, when a 2005 recording showing Trump talking about grabbing women without their permission was made public and when he and his allies sought to prevent the release of other potentially embarrassing stories.\n\nThat effort, prosecutors say, included hush money payments to a porn actor and Playboy model who both have said they had sexual encounters with Trump before he entered politics.\n\nMs Hicks said of the Access Hollywood recording, first revealed in an October 2016 Washington Post story: \"I had a good sense to believe this was going to be a massive story and that it was going to dominate the news cycle for the next several days.\n\n\"This was a damaging development.\"\n\nThe trial enters its third week of testimony on Monday with prosecutors building toward their star witness, Michael Cohen, Trump's former lawyer and personal fixer who pleaded guilty to federal charges related to the hush money payments.\n\nMr Cohen is expected to undergo a bruising cross-examination from defence attorneys seeking to undermine his credibility with jurors.\n\nTrump faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records in connection with payments made to stifle potentially embarrassing stories.\n\nProsecutors say Trump's company, the Trump Organisation, reimbursed Mr Cohen for payments to porn actor Stormy Daniels and gave Mr Cohen bonuses and extra payments. Prosecutors allege that those transactions were falsely logged in company records as legal expenses.\n\nTrump has pleaded not guilty and denied sexual encounters with any of the women, as well as any wrongdoing.\n\nSo far, jurors have heard from witnesses including a tabloid magazine publisher and Trump friend who bought the rights to several sordid tales about Trump to prevent them from coming out and a Los Angeles lawyer who negotiated hush money deals on behalf of both Ms Daniels and Playboy model Karen McDougal.\n\nTrump's lawyers have tried to chip away at the prosecution's theory of the case and the credibility of some witnesses.\n\nThey have raised questions during cross-examinations about whether Trump was possibly a target of extortion, forced to arrange payouts to suppress harmful stories and spare his family embarrassment and pain.\n\nProsecutors maintain the payments were about preserving his political viability as he sought the presidency.\n\nThe case is one of four Trump prosecutions and possibly the only one that will reach trial before the November election.\n\nOther felony indictments charge him with plotting to subvert the 2020 presidential election after he lost to Democrat Joe Biden and illegally hoarding classified documents after he left the White House.", "source": {"uri": "yorkpress.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Press, York"}, "authors": {"uri": "2024-05-346611988", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "14:34:15", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T14:34:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T08:52:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.tribuneindia.com/news/world/donald-trump-fined-1-000-for-gag-order-violation-in-hush-money-case-as-judge-warns-of-possible-jail-time-618534", "title": "Donald Trump fined $1,000 for gag order violation in hush money case as judge warns of possible jail time", "body": "The judge presiding over Donald Trump's hush money trial has fined him $1,000 for violating his gag order and sternly warned the former president that additional violation could result in jail time.\n\nThe fine marks the second sanction for Trump for inflammatory comments about witnesses since the start of the trial last month. He was fined $9,000 last week for nine violations.\n\nJudge Juan M Merchan warned Monday that additional gag order violations could potentially result in jail time, though he said that was \"the last thing I want to do\".\n\nProsecutors in Trump's hush money trial are moving deeper into his orbit following an inside-the-room account about the former president's reaction to a politically damaging recording that surfaced in the final weeks of the 2016 campaign.\n\nHope Hicks, a former White House official and for years a top aide, is by far the closest Trump associate to have taken the witness stand in the Manhattan trial.\n\nHer testimony Friday was designed to give jurors an insider's view of a chaotic and pivotal stretch in the campaign, when a 2005 recording showing Trump talking about grabbing women without their permission was made public and when he and his allies sought to prevent the release of other potentially embarrassing stories.\n\nThat effort, prosecutors say, included hush money payments to a porn actor and Playboy model who both have said they had sexual encounters with Trump before he entered politics.\n\n\"I had a good sense to believe this was going to be a massive story and that it was going to dominate the news cycle for the next several days,\" Hicks said of the \"Access Hollywood\" recording, first revealed in an October 2016 Washington Post story. \"This was a damaging development.\"\n\nThe trial enters its third week of testimony Monday with prosecutors building toward their star witness, Michael Cohen, Trump's former lawyer and personal fixer who pleaded guilty to federal charges related to the hush money payments.\n\nCohen is expected to undergo a bruising cross-examination from defence attorneys seeking to undermine his credibility with jurors.\n\nTrump faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records in connection with payments made to stifle potentially embarrassing stories.\n\nProsecutors say Trump's company, the Trump Organization, reimbursed Cohen for payments to porn actor Stormy Daniels and gave Cohen bonuses and extra payments.\n\nProsecutors allege that those transactions were falsely logged in company records as legal expenses.\n\nTrump has pleaded not guilty and denied sexual encounters with any of the women, as well as any wrongdoing.\n\nSo far, jurors have heard from witnesses including a tabloid magazine publisher and Trump friend who bought the rights to several sordid tales about Trump to prevent them from coming out and a Los Angeles lawyer who negotiated hush money deals on behalf of both Daniels and Playboy model Karen McDougal.\n\nTrump's lawyers have tried to chip away at the prosecution's theory of the case and the credibility of some witnesses. They've raised questions during cross-examinations about whether Trump was possibly a target of extortion, forced to arrange payouts to suppress harmful stories and spare his family embarrassment and pain. Prosecutors maintain the payments were about preserving his political viability as he sought the presidency.\n\nThe case is one of four Trump prosecutions and possibly the only one that will reach trial before the November election. Other felony indictments charge him with plotting to subvert the 2020 presidential election after he lost to Democrat Joe Biden and illegally hoarding classified documents after he left the White {"uri": "8111086391", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "12:32:05", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T12:32:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T12:29:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13382495/Hulk-Hogan-hurricanes-blockbuster-recording-A-week-review-Trump-hush-money-trial.html", "title": "Hulk Hogan, hurricanes and a blockbuster recording: A week in...", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) - Crucial witnesses took the stand in the second week of testimony in Donald Trump's hush money trial, including a California lawyer who negotiated deals at the center of the case and a longtime adviser to the former president.\n\nJurors heard a potentially pivotal piece of evidence - a 2016 recording of Trump discussing a plan to buy a Playboy model's silence - as well as testimony about the wrestler Hulk Hogan and hurricanes, literal and figurative.\n\nOutside the jury's presence, Trump was fined for running afoul of a judge's gag order. Additional sanctions could await the presumptive Republican nominee for president.\n\nA look at some of the highlights from the past week:\n\nHope Hicks, a onetime Trump confidant who for years was central in his orbit, described in detail a seminal moment of the 2016 campaign: The Washington Post's disclosure of a 2005 \"Access Hollywood\" recording in which Trump boasted about grabbing women's genitals without their permission.\n\nHicks acknowledged being \"concerned, very concerned\" when a reporter reached out to her for comment before breaking the story.\n\nFormer President Donald Trump appears at Manhattan criminal court before his trial in New York, Friday, May 3, 2024. (Charly Triballeau/Pool Photo via AP)\n\n\"I had a good sense to believe this was going to be a massive story and that it was going to dominate the news cycle for the next several days,\" Hicks testified. \"This was a damaging development.\"\n\nThe recording, made public just days before a debate with Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton, is relevant to the case because prosecutors believe it helps explain the frenetic efforts by Trump and allies in the campaign's remaining weeks to try to suppress any additional harmful stories that might arise.\n\nIn fact, in the aftermath of the tape\u00b4s release, Hicks said she asked Michael Cohen, Trump's then-lawyer and personal fixer, to hunt down a rumor of another potentially damaging recording. \"There was no such tape regardless,\" Hicks said, \"but he sort of chased that down for me.\"\n\nRegardless, the immediate impact of the \"Access Hollywood\" story was so intense, Hicks recalled, that it took attention away from an actual storm. Hurricane Matthew was dominating the news cycle when Hicks was contacted about the forthcoming story. That didn't last long.\n\n\"The 'Access Hollywood\u00b4 tape pushed the hurricane off the news?\" prosecutor Matthew Colangelo asked.\n\n\"Yes,\" Hicks replied.\n\nTrump may be a criminal defendant, but an element of his defense came into view this past week when one of his lawyers suggested Trump might actually have been a victim.\n\nAttorney Emil Bove implied during a notably tense cross-examination that his client had been effectively targeted for extortion by Keith Davidson, a crucial witness and the lawyer who negotiated hush money deals for two women, porn actor Stormy Daniels and Playboy model Karen McDougal, claiming to have had sexual encounters with Trump. Trump denies it.\n\nBove name-dropped a gaggle of celebrities he suggested had been coerced over the years into paying Davidson's clients eye-popping sums to suppress harmful videos or stories. Among them was actor Charlie Sheen, whom Bove said Davidson had \"extracted sums of money from;\" Davidson took issue with the word \"extract\" but said he had been involved in \"valid settlements\" with Sheen.\n\nDavidson also acknowledge that he had faced an FBI investigation, but was never charged, for allegedly attempting to extort Hogan to head off the release of the professional wrestling star\u00b4s sex tape.\n\nBy 2016, Bove suggested, Davidson was well-versed in the concept of squeezing celebrities such as Trump.\n\n\"And you did everything that you could to get as close to that line as possible in these negotiations without crossing it, right?\" Bove asked.\n\n\"I did everything I could to make sure my activities were lawful,\" Davidson replied.\n\nThe prosecution's key witness, Cohen, has yet to testify - and Trump might never at all - but their voices were played in the courtroom in perhaps the most vivid piece of evidence so far.\n\nProsecutors played aloud a September 2016 recording that Cohen made of himself briefing the then-presidential candidate on a plan to buy McDougal's silence with a $150,000 payment. McDougal was prepared to come forward with her account of an extramarital affair with Trump, a disclosure Trump and his allies were determined to prevent in the final days of the election.\n\n\"What do we got to pay for this? One-fifty?\" Trump can be heard saying at one point.\n\nThey discuss whether the payment should be done with cash or check. Then the recording cuts out.\n\nThough the existence of the recording surfaced in the summer of 2018 and has long been known to the public, its disclosure to the jury was a dramatic moment meant to establish that the hush money payment was done with Trump's knowledge.\n\nHe appeared visibly irritated as the recording was played. Jurors seemed riveted.\n\nThe recording was hardly the only time Cohen surfaced in court over the past week. When he did, it was generally in a negative light.\n\nDavidson said his introduction to Cohen came in 2011 when Davidson was told that he needed to return an angry call from Cohen over a blog post related to Daniels and Trump. Davidson said Cohen was described to him by Daniels' talent manager as \"some jerk\" who have been \"very, very aggressive and threatened to sue me.\"\n\nWhen Davidson called Cohen and introduced himself, \"I was just met with, like, a hustle barrage of insults and insinuations and allegations. That went on for quite a while.\"\n\nDavidson also recounted a memorable phone conversation with Cohen one month after the 2016 election in which the Trump attorney sounded \"depressed and despondent\" and complained about being passed over for a role in the new Trump administration.\n\n\"He said something to the effect of: 'Jesus Christ. Can you (expletive) believe I\u00b4m not going to Washington,\u00b4\" Davidson described Cohen as saying. \"'After everything I\u00b4ve done for that (expletive) guy. I can\u00b4t believe I\u00b4m not going to Washington. I\u00b4ve saved that guy\u00b4s (expletive) so many times, you don\u00b4t even know.'\"\n\nThe uncharitable characterizations may help Trump's team in its efforts to undermine Cohen's credibility. But they could also help prosecutors distance themselves from Cohen, subtly indicating to jurors that he is not a teammate but rather someone who simply has information.\n\nA side issue throughout the trial is what to do about Trump's outside-of-court comments. He repeatedly has maligned witnesses and suggested bias on the jury - all despite a judge's gag order meant to bar him from verbal tirades against key players in the case.\n\nTrump was assessed a $9,000 fine - $1,000 for each of nine separate gag order violations that the judge identified. Prosecutors later requested an additional $4,000 penalty for what they said were additional breaches of the order.\n\nYet it remains unclear what, if anything, Judge Juan M. Merchan can do in the event of continued violations. Merchan floated the possibility of jail, an unprecedented outcome for a former American president. That also would risk inflaming Trump's base as he pursues the presidency and would further upend the 2024 White House race.\n\nTrump's attorneys insist he needs some leeway to be able to respond to relentless criticism, including from witnesses, and that his candidacy means he's the subject of nonstop news media coverage.\n\nMerchan seemed unpersuaded, but jail, for now at least, seems to be no one's desired outcome.\n\n\"Because each of these statements was made before the Court held the Defendant in contempt for violating this order nine previous times, and because we prefer to minimize disruptions to this proceeding, we are not yet seeking jail,\" prosecutor Chris Conroy said.\n\n\"But,\" he added, \"the Court\u00b4s decision this past Tuesday will inform the approach we take to any future violations.\"\n\nFormer President Donald Trump speaks to the media at Manhattan criminal court, Friday, May 3, 2024, in New York. (Jeenah Moon/Pool Photo via AP)\n\nFILE - Hope Hicks, former White House Communications Director, arrives to meet with the House Intelligence Committee, at the Capitol in Washington, Feb. 27, 2018. Prosecutors say Hicks spoke with former President Donald Trump by phone during a frenzied effort to keep allegations of his marital infidelity out of the press after the infamous \"Access Hollywood\" tape leaked weeks before the 2016 election. In the tape, from 2005, Trump boasted about grabbing women without permission. (AP Photo/J. Scott Applewhite, File)\n\nFILE - Michael Cohen arrives at New York Supreme Court Oct. 25, 2023, in New York. Donald Trump's former lawyer and fixer, Cohen was once a fierce Trump ally, but now he's a key prosecution witness against his former boss in the Trump hush money trial. Cohen worked for the Trump Organization from 2006 to 2017. He later went to federal prison after pleading guilty to campaign finance violations relating to the hush-money arrangements and other, unrelated crimes. (AP Photo/Yuki Iwamura, File)\n\nFILE - Stormy Daniels arrives at an event in Berlin, on Oct. 11, 2018. The porn actor received a $130,000 payment from Donald Trump's former lawyer Michael Cohen as part of his hush-money efforts. Cohen paid Daniels to keep quiet about what she says was a sexual encounter with Trump years earlier. Trump denies having sex with Daniels. (AP Photo/Markus Schreiber, File)\n\nEmil Bove, attorney for former President Donald Trump, sits in the courtroom at Manhattan criminal court in New York, Friday, May 3, 2024. (Jeenah Moon/Pool Photo via AP)\n\nFormer President Donald Trump Former President Donald Trump speaks to media as he returns to his trial at the Manhattan Criminal Court, Friday, May 3, 2024, in New York. {"uri": "2024-05-345271197", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "23:10:05", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T23:10:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T11:59:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.mcall.com/2024/05/04/hulk-hogan-hurricanes-and-a-blockbuster-recording-a-week-in-review-of-the-trump-hush-money-trial/", "title": "Hulk Hogan, hurricanes and a blockbuster recording: A week in review of the Trump hush money trial", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Crucial witnesses took the stand in the second week of testimony in Donald Trump's hush money trial, including a California lawyer who negotiated deals at the center of the case and a longtime adviser to the former president.\n\nJurors heard a potentially pivotal piece of evidence -- a 2016 recording of Trump discussing a plan to buy a Playboy model's silence -- as well as testimony about the wrestler Hulk Hogan and hurricanes, literal and figurative.\n\nOutside the jury's presence, Trump was fined for running afoul of a judge's gag order. Additional sanctions could await the presumptive Republican nominee for president.\n\nA look at some of the highlights from the past week:\n\nHope Hicks, a onetime Trump confidant who for years was central in his orbit, described in detail a seminal moment of the 2016 campaign: The Washington Post's disclosure of a 2005 \"Access Hollywood\" recording in which Trump boasted about grabbing women's genitals without their permission.\n\nHicks acknowledged being \"concerned, very concerned\" when a reporter reached out to her for comment before breaking the story.\n\n\"I had a good sense to believe this was going to be a massive story and that it was going to dominate the news cycle for the next several days,\" Hicks testified. \"This was a damaging development.\"\n\nThe recording, made public just days before a debate with Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton, is relevant to the case because prosecutors believe it helps explain the frenetic efforts by Trump and allies in the campaign's remaining weeks to try to suppress any additional harmful stories that might arise.\n\nIn fact, in the aftermath of the tape's release, Hicks said she asked Michael Cohen, Trump's then-lawyer and personal fixer, to hunt down a rumor of another potentially damaging recording. \"There was no such tape regardless,\" Hicks said, \"but he sort of chased that down for me.\"\n\nRegardless, the immediate impact of the \"Access Hollywood\" story was so intense, Hicks recalled, that it took attention away from an actual storm. Hurricane Matthew was dominating the news cycle when Hicks was contacted about the forthcoming story. That didn't last long.\n\n\"The 'Access Hollywood' tape pushed the hurricane off the news?\" prosecutor Matthew Colangelo asked.\n\n\"Yes,\" Hicks replied.\n\nTrump may be a criminal defendant, but an element of his defense came into view this past week when one of his lawyers suggested Trump might actually have been a victim.\n\nAttorney Emil Bove implied during a notably tense cross-examination that his client had been effectively targeted for extortion by Keith Davidson, a crucial witness and the lawyer who negotiated hush money deals for two women, porn actor Stormy Daniels and Playboy model Karen McDougal, claiming to have had sexual encounters with Trump. Trump denies it.\n\nBove name-dropped a gaggle of celebrities he suggested had been coerced over the years into paying Davidson's clients eye-popping sums to suppress harmful videos or stories. Among them was actor Charlie Sheen, whom Bove said Davidson had \"extracted sums of money from;\" Davidson took issue with the word \"extract\" but said he had been involved in \"valid settlements\" with Sheen.\n\nDavidson also acknowledge that he had faced an FBI investigation, but was never charged, for allegedly attempting to extort Hogan to head off the release of the professional wrestling star's sex tape.\n\nBy 2016, Bove suggested, Davidson was well-versed in the concept of squeezing celebrities such as Trump.\n\n\"And you did everything that you could to get as close to that line as possible in these negotiations without crossing it, right?\" Bove asked.\n\n\"I did everything I could to make sure my activities were lawful,\" Davidson replied.\n\nThe prosecution's key witness, Cohen, has yet to testify -- and Trump might never at all -- but their voices were played in the courtroom in perhaps the most vivid piece of evidence so far.\n\nProsecutors played aloud a September 2016 recording that Cohen made of himself briefing the then-presidential candidate on a plan to buy McDougal's silence with a $150,000 payment. McDougal was prepared to come forward with her account of an extramarital affair with Trump, a disclosure Trump and his allies were determined to prevent in the final days of the election.\n\n\"What do we got to pay for this? One-fifty?\" Trump can be heard saying at one point.\n\nThey discuss whether the payment should be done with cash or check. Then the recording cuts out.\n\nThough the existence of the recording surfaced in the summer of 2018 and has long been known to the public, its disclosure to the jury was a dramatic moment meant to establish that the hush money payment was done with Trump's knowledge.\n\nHe appeared visibly irritated as the recording was played. Jurors seemed riveted.\n\nThe recording was hardly the only time Cohen surfaced in court over the past week. When he did, it was generally in a negative light.\n\nDavidson said his introduction to Cohen came in 2011 when Davidson was told that he needed to return an angry call from Cohen over a blog post related to Daniels and Trump. Davidson said Cohen was described to him by Daniels' talent manager as \"some jerk\" who have been \"very, very aggressive and threatened to sue me.\"\n\nWhen Davidson called Cohen and introduced himself, \"I was just met with, like, a hustle barrage of insults and insinuations and allegations. That went on for quite a while.\"\n\nDavidson also recounted a memorable phone conversation with Cohen one month after the 2016 election in which the Trump attorney sounded \"depressed and despondent\" and complained about being passed over for a role in the new Trump administration.\n\n\"He said something to the effect of: 'Jesus Christ. Can you (expletive) believe I'm not going to Washington,'\" Davidson described Cohen as saying. \"'After everything I've done for that (expletive) guy. I can't believe I'm not going to Washington. I've saved that guy's (expletive) so many times, you don't even know.'\"\n\nThe uncharitable characterizations may help Trump's team in its efforts to undermine Cohen's credibility. But they could also help prosecutors distance themselves from Cohen, subtly indicating to jurors that he is not a teammate but rather someone who simply has information.\n\nA side issue throughout the trial is what to do about Trump's outside-of-court comments. He repeatedly has maligned witnesses and suggested bias on the jury -- all despite a judge's gag order meant to bar him from verbal tirades against key players in the case.\n\nTrump was assessed a $9,000 fine -- $1,000 for each of nine separate gag order violations that the judge identified. Prosecutors later requested an additional $4,000 penalty for what they said were additional breaches of the order.\n\nYet it remains unclear what, if anything, Judge Juan M. Merchan can do in the event of continued violations. Merchan floated the possibility of jail, an unprecedented outcome for a former American president. That also would risk inflaming Trump's base as he pursues the presidency and would further upend the 2024 White House race.\n\nTrump's attorneys insist he needs some leeway to be able to respond to relentless criticism, including from witnesses, and that his candidacy means he's the subject of nonstop news media coverage.\n\nMerchan seemed unpersuaded, but jail, for now at least, seems to be no one's desired outcome.\n\n\"Because each of these statements was made before the Court held the Defendant in contempt for violating this order nine previous times, and because we prefer to minimize disruptions to this proceeding, we are not yet seeking jail,\" prosecutor Chris Conroy said.\n\n\"But,\" he added, \"the Court's decision this past Tuesday will inform the approach we take to any future violations.\"", "source": {"uri": "mcall.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Morning Call"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@mcall.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", Testimony resumes on Monday.\n\nWASHINGTON -- Crucial witnesses took the stand in the second week of testimony in Donald Trump's hush money trial, including a California lawyer who negotiated deals at the center of the case and a longtime adviser to the former president.\n\nJurors heard a potentially pivotal piece of evidence -- a 2016 recording of Trump discussing a plan to buy a Playboy model's silence -- as well as testimony about the wrestler Hulk Hogan and hurricanes, literal and figurative.\n\nOutside the jury's presence, Trump was fined for running afoul of a judge's gag order. Additional sanctions could await the presumptive Republican nominee for president.\n\nHere's some of the highlights from the past week:\n\nA political hurricane ... and an actual one\n\nHope Hicks, a onetime Trump confidant who for years was central in his orbit, described in detail a seminal moment of the 2016 campaign: The Washington Post's disclosure of a 2005 \"Access Hollywood\" recording in which Trump boasted about groping women without their permission.\n\nHicks acknowledged being \"concerned, very concerned\" when a reporter reached out to her for comment before breaking the story.\n\n\"I had a good sense to believe this was going to be a massive story and that it was going to dominate the news cycle for the next several days,\" Hicks testified. \"This was a damaging development.\"\n\nThe recording, made public just days before a debate with Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton, is relevant to the case because prosecutors believe it helps explain the frenetic efforts by Trump and allies in the campaign's remaining weeks to try to suppress any additional harmful stories that might arise.\n\nIn the aftermath of the tape's release, Hicks said she asked Michael Cohen, Trump's then-lawyer and personal fixer, to hunt down a rumor of another potentially damaging recording. \"There was no such tape regardless,\" Hicks said, \"but he sort of chased that down for me.\"\n\nThe immediate impact of the \"Access Hollywood\" story was so intense, Hicks recalled, that it took attention away from an actual storm. Hurricane Matthew was dominating the news cycle when Hicks was contacted about the forthcoming story. That didn't last long.\n\n\"The 'Access Hollywood' tape pushed the hurricane off the news?\" prosecutor Matthew Colangelo asked.\n\n\"Yes,\" Hicks replied.\n\nTrump the extortion target?\n\nTrump may be a criminal defendant, but an element of his defense came into view this past week when one of his lawyers suggested Trump might have been a victim.\n\nAttorney Emil Bove implied during a notably tense cross-examination that his client was effectively targeted for extortion by Keith Davidson, a crucial witness and the lawyer who negotiated hush money deals for two women -- porn actor Stormy Daniels and Playboy model Karen McDougal -- who claimed to have had sexual encounters with Trump. Trump denies it.\n\nBove name-dropped a gaggle of celebrities he suggested were coerced over the years into paying Davidson's clients eye-popping sums to suppress harmful videos or stories. Among them was actor Charlie Sheen, whom Bove said Davidson \"extracted sums of money from\"; Davidson took issue with the word \"extract\" but said he was involved in \"valid settlements\" with Sheen.\n\nDavidson also acknowledged he faced an FBI investigation but was never charged for allegedly attempting to extort Hogan to head off the release of the professional wrestling star's sex tape.\n\nBy 2016, Bove suggested, Davidson was well-versed in the concept of squeezing celebrities such as Trump.\n\n\"And you did everything that you could to get as close to that line as possible in these negotiations without crossing it, right?\" Bove asked.\n\n\"I did everything I could to make sure my activities were lawful,\" Davidson replied.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n'What do we got to pay for this?'\n\nThe prosecution's key witness, Cohen, has yet to testify -- and Trump might never at all -- but their voices were played in the courtroom in perhaps the most vivid piece of evidence so far.\n\nProsecutors played aloud a September 2016 recording that Cohen made of himself briefing the then-presidential candidate on a plan to buy McDougal's silence with a $150,000 payment. McDougal was prepared to come forward with her account of an extramarital affair with Trump, a disclosure Trump and his allies were determined to prevent in the final days of the election.\n\n\"What do we got to pay for this? One-fifty?\" Trump can be heard saying at one point.\n\nThey discuss whether the payment should be done with cash or check. Then the recording cuts out.\n\nThough the existence of the recording surfaced in the summer of 2018 and has long been known to the public, its disclosure to the jury was a dramatic moment meant to establish that the hush money payment was done with Trump's knowledge.\n\nHe appeared visibly irritated as the recording was played. Jurors seemed riveted.\n\nThe recording was hardly the only time Cohen surfaced in court over the past week. When he did, it was generally in a negative light.\n\nDavidson said his introduction to Cohen came in 2011, when Davidson was told that he needed to return an angry call from Cohen over a blog post related to Daniels and Trump. Davidson said Cohen was described to him by Daniels' talent manager as \"some jerk\" who was \"very, very aggressive and threatened to sue me.\"\n\nWhen Davidson called Cohen and introduced himself, \"I was just met with, like, a hustle barrage of insults and insinuations and allegations. That went on for quite a while.\"\n\nDavidson also recounted a memorable phone conversation with Cohen one month after the 2016 election in which the Trump attorney sounded \"depressed and despondent\" and complained about being passed over for a role in the new Trump administration.\n\n\"He said something to the effect of: 'Jesus Christ. Can you (expletive) believe I'm not going to Washington,'\" Davidson described Cohen as saying. \"'After everything I've done for that (expletive) guy. I can't believe I'm not going to Washington. I've saved that guy's (expletive) so many times, you don't even know.'\"\n\nThe uncharitable characterizations may help Trump's team in its efforts to undermine Cohen's credibility. But they also could help prosecutors distance themselves from Cohen, subtly indicating to jurors that he is not a teammate but rather someone who simply has information.\n\nTo jail a president\n\nA side issue throughout the trial is what to do about Trump's outside-of-court comments. He repeatedly maligned witnesses and suggested bias on the jury -- all despite a judge's gag order meant to bar him from verbal tirades against key players in the case.\n\nTrump was assessed a $9,000 fine -- $1,000 for each of nine separate gag order violations the judge identified. Prosecutors later requested an additional $4,000 penalty for what they said were additional breaches of the order.\n\nYet it remains unclear what, if anything, Judge Juan M. Merchan can do in the event of continued violations. Merchan floated the possibility of jail, which would be unprecedented for a former American president. That also would risk inflaming Trump's base as he pursues the presidency and would further upend the 2024 White House race.\n\nTrump's attorneys insist he needs some leeway to be able to respond to relentless criticism, including from witnesses, and that his candidacy means he's the subject of nonstop news media coverage.\n\nMerchan seemed unpersuaded but jail, for now at least, seems to be no one's desired outcome.\n\n\"Because each of these statements was made before the Court held the Defendant in contempt for violating this order nine previous times, and because we prefer to minimize disruptions to this proceeding, we are not yet seeking jail,\" prosecutor Chris Conroy said.\n\n\"But,\" he added, \"the Court's decision this past Tuesday will inform the approach we take to any future violations.\"\n\nPhotos: Scenes from Donald Trump's hush money trial", "source": {"uri": "magicvalley.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Magic Valley"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-344910171", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "12:23:58", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T12:23:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T11:59:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.maryvilleforum.com/news/wire/hulk-hogan-hurricanes-and-a-blockbuster-recording-a-week-in-review-of-the-trump-hush/article_8549047d-1bc1-55e4-86d2-42431ae64ee9.html", "title": "Hulk Hogan, hurricanes and a blockbuster recording: A week in review of the Trump hush money trial", "body": "Crucial witnesses took the stand in the second week of testimony in Donald Trump's hush money trial in New York\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- Crucial witnesses took the stand in the second week of testimony in Donald Trump's hush money trial, including a California lawyer who negotiated deals at the center of the case and a longtime adviser to the former president.\n\nJurors heard a potentially pivotal piece of evidence -- a 2016 recording of Trump discussing a plan to buy a Playboy model's silence -- as well as testimony about the wrestler Hulk Hogan and hurricanes, literal and figurative.\n\nOutside the jury's presence, Trump was fined for running afoul of a judge's gag order. Additional sanctions could await the presumptive Republican nominee for president.\n\nA look at some of the highlights from the past week:\n\nA POLITICAL HURRICANE ... AND AN ACTUAL ONE\n\nHope Hicks, a onetime Trump confidant who for years was central in his orbit, described in detail a seminal moment of the 2016 campaign: The Washington Post's disclosure of a 2005 \"Access Hollywood\" recording in which Trump boasted about grabbing women's genitals without their permission.\n\nHicks acknowledged being \"concerned, very concerned\" when a reporter reached out to her for comment before breaking the story.\n\n\"I had a good sense to believe this was going to be a massive story and that it was going to dominate the news cycle for the next several days,\" Hicks testified. \"This was a damaging development.\"\n\nThe recording, made public just days before a debate with Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton, is relevant to the case because prosecutors believe it helps explain the frenetic efforts by Trump and allies in the campaign's remaining weeks to try to suppress any additional harmful stories that might arise.\n\nIn fact, in the aftermath of the tape's release, Hicks said she asked Michael Cohen, Trump's then-lawyer and personal fixer, to hunt down a rumor of another potentially damaging recording. \"There was no such tape regardless,\" Hicks said, \"but he sort of chased that down for me.\"\n\nRegardless, the immediate impact of the \"Access Hollywood\" story was so intense, Hicks recalled, that it took attention away from an actual storm. Hurricane Matthew was dominating the news cycle when Hicks was contacted about the forthcoming story. That didn't last long.\n\n\"The 'Access Hollywood' tape pushed the hurricane off the news?\" prosecutor Matthew Colangelo asked.\n\n\"Yes,\" Hicks replied.\n\nTRUMP THE EXTORTION TARGET?\n\nTrump may be a criminal defendant, but an element of his defense came into view this past week when one of his lawyers suggested Trump might actually have been a victim.\n\nAttorney Emil Bove implied during a notably tense cross-examination that his client had been effectively targeted for extortion by Keith Davidson, a crucial witness and the lawyer who negotiated hush money deals for two women, porn actor Stormy Daniels and Playboy model Karen McDougal, claiming to have had sexual encounters with Trump. Trump denies it.\n\nBove name-dropped a gaggle of celebrities he suggested had been coerced over the years into paying Davidson's clients eye-popping sums to suppress harmful videos or stories. Among them was actor Charlie Sheen, whom Bove said Davidson had \"extracted sums of money from;\" Davidson took issue with the word \"extract\" but said he had been involved in \"valid settlements\" with Sheen.\n\nDavidson also acknowledge that he had faced an FBI investigation, but was never charged, for allegedly attempting to extort Hogan to head off the release of the professional wrestling star's sex tape.\n\nBy 2016, Bove suggested, Davidson was well-versed in the concept of squeezing celebrities such as Trump.\n\n\"And you did everything that you could to get as close to that line as possible in these negotiations without crossing it, right?\" Bove asked.\n\n\"I did everything I could to make sure my activities were lawful,\" Davidson replied.\n\n'WHAT DO WE GOT TO PAY FOR THIS?'\n\nThe prosecution's key witness, Cohen, has yet to testify -- and Trump might never at all -- but their voices were played in the courtroom in perhaps the most vivid piece of evidence so far.\n\nProsecutors played aloud a September 2016 recording that Cohen made of himself briefing the then-presidential candidate on a plan to buy McDougal's silence with a $150,000 payment. McDougal was prepared to come forward with her account of an extramarital affair with Trump, a disclosure Trump and his allies were determined to prevent in the final days of the election.\n\n\"What do we got to pay for this? One-fifty?\" Trump can be heard saying at one point.\n\nThey discuss whether the payment should be done with cash or check. Then the recording cuts out.\n\nThough the existence of the recording surfaced in the summer of 2018 and has long been known to the public, its disclosure to the jury was a dramatic moment meant to establish that the hush money payment was done with Trump's knowledge.\n\nHe appeared visibly irritated as the recording was played. Jurors seemed riveted.\n\nTHE 'JERK'\n\nThe recording was hardly the only time Cohen surfaced in court over the past week. When he did, it was generally in a negative light.\n\nDavidson said his introduction to Cohen came in 2011 when Davidson was told that he needed to return an angry call from Cohen over a blog post related to Daniels and Trump. Davidson said Cohen was described to him by Daniels' talent manager as \"some jerk\" who have been \"very, very aggressive and threatened to sue me.\"\n\nWhen Davidson called Cohen and introduced himself, \"I was just met with, like, a hustle barrage of insults and insinuations and allegations. That went on for quite a while.\"\n\nDavidson also recounted a memorable phone conversation with Cohen one month after the 2016 election in which the Trump attorney sounded \"depressed and despondent\" and complained about being passed over for a role in the new Trump administration.\n\n\"He said something to the effect of: 'Jesus Christ. Can you (expletive) believe I'm not going to Washington,'\" Davidson described Cohen as saying. \"'After everything I've done for that (expletive) guy. I can't believe I'm not going to Washington. I've saved that guy's (expletive) so many times, you don't even know.'\"\n\nThe uncharitable characterizations may help Trump's team in its efforts to undermine Cohen's credibility. But they could also help prosecutors distance themselves from Cohen, subtly indicating to jurors that he is not a teammate but rather someone who simply has information.\n\nTO JAIL A PRESIDENT\n\nA side issue throughout the trial is what to do about Trump's outside-of-court comments. He repeatedly has maligned witnesses and suggested bias on the jury -- all despite a judge's gag order meant to bar him from verbal tirades against key players in the case.\n\nTrump was assessed a $9,000 fine -- $1,000 for each of nine separate gag order violations that the judge identified. Prosecutors later requested an additional $4,000 penalty for what they said were additional breaches of the order.\n\nYet it remains unclear what, if anything, Judge Juan M. Merchan can do in the event of continued violations. Merchan floated the possibility of jail, an unprecedented outcome for a former American president. That also would risk inflaming Trump's base as he pursues the presidency and would further upend the 2024 White House race.\n\nTrump's attorneys insist he needs some leeway to be able to respond to relentless criticism, including from witnesses, and that his candidacy means he's the subject of nonstop news media coverage.\n\nMerchan seemed unpersuaded, but jail, for now at least, seems to be no one's desired outcome.\n\n\"Because each of these statements was made before the Court held the Defendant in contempt for violating this order nine previous times, and because we prefer to minimize disruptions to this proceeding, we are not yet seeking jail,\" prosecutor Chris Conroy said.\n\n\"But,\" he added, \"the Court's decision this past Tuesday will inform the approach we take to any {"uri": "8111591066", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "21:30:49", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T21:30:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T21:29:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://dothaneagle.com/news/nation-world/crime-courts/courts-election-interference-cohen/article_c509e376-04f7-5bed-b8a9-69386840b7aa.html", "title": "Hulk Hogan, hurricanes and a blockbuster recording: A review of Trump trial's second week", "body": "WASHINGTON -- Crucial witnesses took the stand in the second week of testimony in Donald Trump's hush money trial, including a California lawyer who negotiated deals at the center of the case and a longtime adviser to the former president.\n\nJurors heard a potentially pivotal piece of evidence -- a 2016 recording of Trump discussing a plan to buy a Playboy model's silence -- as well as testimony about the wrestler Hulk Hogan and hurricanes, literal and figurative.\n\nOutside the jury's presence, Trump was fined for running afoul of a judge's gag order. Additional sanctions could await the presumptive Republican nominee for president.\n\nHere's some of the highlights from the past week:\n\nA political hurricane ... and an actual one\n\nHope Hicks, a onetime Trump confidant who for years was central in his orbit, described in detail a seminal moment of the 2016 campaign: The Washington Post's disclosure of a 2005 \"Access Hollywood\" recording in which Trump boasted about groping women without their permission.\n\nHicks acknowledged being \"concerned, very concerned\" when a reporter reached out to her for comment before breaking the story.\n\n\"I had a good sense to believe this was going to be a massive story and that it was going to dominate the news cycle for the next several days,\" Hicks testified. \"This was a damaging development.\"\n\nThe recording, made public just days before a debate with Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton, is relevant to the case because prosecutors believe it helps explain the frenetic efforts by Trump and allies in the campaign's remaining weeks to try to suppress any additional harmful stories that might arise.\n\nIn the aftermath of the tape's release, Hicks said she asked Michael Cohen, Trump's then-lawyer and personal fixer, to hunt down a rumor of another potentially damaging recording. \"There was no such tape regardless,\" Hicks said, \"but he sort of chased that down for me.\"\n\nThe immediate impact of the \"Access Hollywood\" story was so intense, Hicks recalled, that it took attention away from an actual storm. Hurricane Matthew was dominating the news cycle when Hicks was contacted about the forthcoming story. That didn't last long.\n\n\"The 'Access Hollywood' tape pushed the hurricane off the news?\" prosecutor Matthew Colangelo asked.\n\n\"Yes,\" Hicks replied.\n\nTrump the extortion target?\n\nTrump may be a criminal defendant, but an element of his defense came into view this past week when one of his lawyers suggested Trump might have been a victim.\n\nAttorney Emil Bove implied during a notably tense cross-examination that his client was effectively targeted for extortion by Keith Davidson, a crucial witness and the lawyer who negotiated hush money deals for two women -- porn actor Stormy Daniels and Playboy model Karen McDougal -- who claimed to have had sexual encounters with Trump. Trump denies it.\n\nBove name-dropped a gaggle of celebrities he suggested were coerced over the years into paying Davidson's clients eye-popping sums to suppress harmful videos or stories. Among them was actor Charlie Sheen, whom Bove said Davidson \"extracted sums of money from\"; Davidson took issue with the word \"extract\" but said he was involved in \"valid settlements\" with Sheen.\n\nDavidson also acknowledged he faced an FBI investigation but was never charged for allegedly attempting to extort Hogan to head off the release of the professional wrestling star's sex tape.\n\nBy 2016, Bove suggested, Davidson was well-versed in the concept of squeezing celebrities such as Trump.\n\n\"And you did everything that you could to get as close to that line as possible in these negotiations without crossing it, right?\" Bove asked.\n\n\"I did everything I could to make sure my activities were lawful,\" Davidson replied.\n\n'What do we got to pay for this?'\n\nThe prosecution's key witness, Cohen, has yet to testify -- and Trump might never at all -- but their voices were played in the courtroom in perhaps the most vivid piece of evidence so far.\n\nProsecutors played aloud a September 2016 recording that Cohen made of himself briefing the then-presidential candidate on a plan to buy McDougal's silence with a $150,000 payment. McDougal was prepared to come forward with her account of an extramarital affair with Trump, a disclosure Trump and his allies were determined to prevent in the final days of the election.\n\n\"What do we got to pay for this? One-fifty?\" Trump can be heard saying at one point.\n\nThey discuss whether the payment should be done with cash or check. Then the recording cuts out.\n\nThough the existence of the recording surfaced in the summer of 2018 and has long been known to the public, its disclosure to the jury was a dramatic moment meant to establish that the hush money payment was done with Trump's knowledge.\n\nHe appeared visibly irritated as the recording was played. Jurors seemed riveted.\n\nThe recording was hardly the only time Cohen surfaced in court over the past week. When he did, it was generally in a negative light.\n\nDavidson said his introduction to Cohen came in 2011, when Davidson was told that he needed to return an angry call from Cohen over a blog post related to Daniels and Trump. Davidson said Cohen was described to him by Daniels' talent manager as \"some jerk\" who was \"very, very aggressive and threatened to sue me.\"\n\nWhen Davidson called Cohen and introduced himself, \"I was just met with, like, a hustle barrage of insults and insinuations and allegations. That went on for quite a while.\"\n\nDavidson also recounted a memorable phone conversation with Cohen one month after the 2016 election in which the Trump attorney sounded \"depressed and despondent\" and complained about being passed over for a role in the new Trump administration.\n\n\"He said something to the effect of: 'Jesus Christ. Can you (expletive) believe I'm not going to Washington,'\" Davidson described Cohen as saying. \"'After everything I've done for that (expletive) guy. I can't believe I'm not going to Washington. I've saved that guy's (expletive) so many times, you don't even know.'\"\n\nThe uncharitable characterizations may help Trump's team in its efforts to undermine Cohen's credibility. But they also could help prosecutors distance themselves from Cohen, subtly indicating to jurors that he is not a teammate but rather someone who simply has information.\n\nTo jail a president\n\nA side issue throughout the trial is what to do about Trump's outside-of-court comments. He repeatedly maligned witnesses and suggested bias on the jury -- all despite a judge's gag order meant to bar him from verbal tirades against key players in the case.\n\nTrump was assessed a $9,000 fine -- $1,000 for each of nine separate gag order violations the judge identified. Prosecutors later requested an additional $4,000 penalty for what they said were additional breaches of the order.\n\nYet it remains unclear what, if anything, Judge Juan M. Merchan can do in the event of continued violations. Merchan floated the possibility of jail, which would be unprecedented for a former American president. That also would risk inflaming Trump's base as he pursues the presidency and would further upend the 2024 White House race.\n\nTrump's attorneys insist he needs some leeway to be able to respond to relentless criticism, including from witnesses, and that his candidacy means he's the subject of nonstop news media coverage.\n\nMerchan seemed unpersuaded but jail, for now at least, seems to be no one's desired outcome.\n\n\"Because each of these statements was made before the Court held the Defendant in contempt for violating this order nine previous times, and because we prefer to minimize disruptions to this proceeding, we are not yet seeking jail,\" prosecutor Chris Conroy said.\n\n\"But,\" he added, \"the Court's decision this past Tuesday will inform the approach we take to any future violations.\"\n\nPhotos: Scenes from Donald Trump's hush money trial Tags Wire Dcc Lee-national Be the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and {"uri": "2024-05-346546082", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "13:35:34", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T13:35:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T13:29:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://wgntv.com/news/ap-the-latest-third-week-of-witness-testimony-in-trumps-hush-money-trial-is-set-to-kick-off/", "title": "Third week of witness testimony in Trump's hush money trial is set to kick off", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) -- Witness testimony in Donald Trump's hush money trial is set to resume Monday morning, setting the stage for an even deeper dive into the events and people involved in what prosecutors have said was a scheme to influence the 2016 presidential election by buying and burying negative stories about the then-candidate.\n\nThe trial is in its 12th day.\n\nFormer Trump adviser Hope Hicks took the stand last week, recounting how Trump's campaign was turned upside-down following the leak of a video wherein he bragged about grabbing women without their permission.\n\nKeith Davidson, who represented porn actor Stormy Daniels and former Playboy model Karen McDougal in hush money negotiations, also took the stand. Davidson spent hours detailing his role in securing payouts for Daniels and McDougal in exchange for their silence about previous sexual encounters they said they had with Trump.\n\nTrump also faced a second contempt hearing over whether he had again violated his gag order over four more prospective violations. Judge Juan M. Merchan has not yet ruled on that sanctions request. Trump was fined $9,000 last Tuesday over nine gag order violations.\n\nOverall, prosecutors are setting the stage for pivotal testimony from Michael Cohen, who paid Daniels $130,000 for her silence before he went to prison for the hush money scheme.\n\nTrump is accused of falsifying internal business records to cover up hush money payments -- including the payment to Daniels -- recording them instead as legal expenses.\n\nTrump has pleaded not guilty to 34 felony counts of falsifying business records.\n\nThe case is the first-ever criminal trial of a former U.S. president and the first of four prosecutions of Trump to reach a jury.\n\nCurrently:\n\n-- Hush money, catch and kill and more: Terms to know in Trump trial\n\n-- What Trump's gag order means in his hush money case\n\n-- Key players: Who's who at Donald Trump's hush money criminal trial\n\n-- The hush money case is just one of Trump's legal cases. See the others here\n\n-- Hulk Hogan, hurricanes and a blockbuster recording: A week in the Trump hush money trial\n\nHere's the latest:\n\nTRUMP TALKS COLUMBIA COMMENCEMENT CANCELLATION BEFORE COURT\n\nBefore heading into the courtroom Monday morning, Donald Trump spoke to reporters, relaying familiar complaints about the fairness of the trial, the judge and the gag order that stops him commenting on witnesses and jurors.\n\nHe also noted the breaking news that Columbia University canceled its main commencement following weeks of pro-Palestinian protests.\n\nDonald Trump has arrived at the courthouse in lower Manhattan as witness testimony in his hush money trial enters its third week.\n\nWitness testimony in Donald Trump's criminal trial is entering its third week on Monday and it remains to be seen who will take the stand next.\n\nOver the past couple weeks, jurors have heard from a host of different people.\n\nFollowing a weeklong jury selection process that began mid-April, jurors heard first from former National Enquirer publisher David Pecker, who among other things explained his pledge to be the \"eyes and ears\" of Trump's 2016 presidential campaign.\n\nKeith Davidson, a lawyer who represented porn actor Stormy Daniels and former Playboy model Karen McDougal in hush money negotiations, also took the stand. And jurors heard from others such as a forensic analyst who examined Michael Cohen's phones and a paralegal with the Manhattan district attorney's office.\n\nFormer White House press secretary and ex-Trump adviser Hope Hicks on Friday painted a vivid picture of the chaos that unfolded after the \"Access Hollywood\" tape leaked and the Wall Street Journal ran a story about McDougal's hush money deal.\n\nThe defense cross-examined Hicks for roughly 20 minutes before court adjourned early last Friday.\n\nTHE WITNESS HEARD, BUT NOT YET SEEN\n\nAlthough an ensemble of different people have testified in Donald Trump's hush money case over the past two weeks, one pivotal witness has been frequently heard but not yet seen: Michael Cohen, Trump's former lawyer and personal fixer.\n\nJurors last week began hearing Cohen's words on audio recordings as prosecutors worked to directly tie Trump to payments to silence women with damaging claims about him before the 2016 election.\n\nJurors heard, in particular, a potentially crucial piece of evidence: a recording of Trump and Cohen, then his attorney, discussing a plan to pay off an ex-Playboy model who claimed to have an affair with Trump. The former president denies the affair.\n\nThey also heard a few witnesses recount their interactions with Cohen -- some pleasant and others far less so.\n\nIt's unclear when the prosecution's star witness will take the stand.\n\nTRUMP EXPECTED IN COURT AS TRIAL ENTERS 12TH DAY\n\nDonald Trump is expected to return to Manhattan court as his hush money trial enters its 12th day.\n\nLast week's proceedings saw a frenzy of witnesses take the stand, including former Trump adviser Hope Hicks and Keith Davidson, a lawyer who represented porn actor Stormy Daniels and former Playboy model Karen McDougal in hush money negotiations with Cohen and the National Enquirer.\n\nThe week also saw Trump fined $9,000 by Judge Juan M. Merchan for violating a gag order that bars the former president from speaking publicly about key witnesses, jurors and others in the case. A second contempt hearing was held on Thursday over four more prospective violations, but Merchan did not immediately issue a decision.", "source": {"uri": "wgntv.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8111081208", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "12:24:04", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T12:24:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T12:23:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/hulk-hogan-hurricanes-and-a-blockbuster-recording-a-week-in-review-of-the-trump-hush/article_36d79e04-abaa-5801-857b-3d04f22c7493.html", "title": "Hulk Hogan, hurricanes and a blockbuster recording: A week in review of the Trump hush money trial", "body": "Former President Donald Trump, center, talks with defense attorney Emil Bove, left, before the start of trial at Manhattan criminal court, Friday, May 3, 2024 in New York.\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- Crucial witnesses took the stand in the second week of testimony in Donald Trump's hush money trial, including a California lawyer who negotiated deals at the center of the case and a longtime adviser to the former president.\n\nJurors heard a potentially pivotal piece of evidence -- a 2016 recording of Trump discussing a plan to buy a Playboy model's silence -- as well as testimony about the wrestler Hulk Hogan and hurricanes, literal and figurative.\n\nOutside the jury's presence, Trump was fined for running afoul of a judge's gag order. Additional sanctions could await the presumptive Republican nominee for president.\n\nA look at some of the highlights from the past week:\n\nA POLITICAL HURRICANE ... AND AN ACTUAL ONE\n\nHope Hicks, a onetime Trump confidant who for years was central in his orbit, described in detail a seminal moment of the 2016 campaign: The Washington Post's disclosure of a 2005 \"Access Hollywood\" recording in which Trump boasted about grabbing women's genitals without their permission.\n\nHicks acknowledged being \"concerned, very concerned\" when a reporter reached out to her for comment before breaking the story.\n\n\"I had a good sense to believe this was going to be a massive story and that it was going to dominate the news cycle for the next several days,\" Hicks testified. \"This was a damaging development.\"\n\nThe recording, made public just days before a debate with Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton, is relevant to the case because prosecutors believe it helps explain the frenetic efforts by Trump and allies in the campaign's remaining weeks to try to suppress any additional harmful stories that might arise.\n\nIn fact, in the aftermath of the tape's release, Hicks said she asked Michael Cohen, Trump's then-lawyer and personal fixer, to hunt down a rumor of another potentially damaging recording. \"There was no such tape regardless,\" Hicks said, \"but he sort of chased that down for me.\"\n\nRegardless, the immediate impact of the \"Access Hollywood\" story was so intense, Hicks recalled, that it took attention away from an actual storm. Hurricane Matthew was dominating the news cycle when Hicks was contacted about the forthcoming story. That didn't last long.\n\n\"The 'Access Hollywood' tape pushed the hurricane off the news?\" prosecutor Matthew Colangelo asked.\n\n\"Yes,\" Hicks replied.\n\nTRUMP THE EXTORTION TARGET?\n\nTrump may be a criminal defendant, but an element of his defense came into view this past week when one of his lawyers suggested Trump might actually have been a victim.\n\nAttorney Emil Bove implied during a notably tense cross-examination that his client had been effectively targeted for extortion by Keith Davidson, a crucial witness and the lawyer who negotiated hush money deals for two women, porn actor Stormy Daniels and Playboy model Karen McDougal, claiming to have had sexual encounters with Trump. Trump denies it.\n\nBove name-dropped a gaggle of celebrities he suggested had been coerced over the years into paying Davidson's clients eye-popping sums to suppress harmful videos or stories. Among them was actor Charlie Sheen, whom Bove said Davidson had \"extracted sums of money from;\" Davidson took issue with the word \"extract\" but said he had been involved in \"valid settlements\" with Sheen.\n\nDavidson also acknowledge that he had faced an FBI investigation, but was never charged, for allegedly attempting to extort Hogan to head off the release of the professional wrestling star's sex tape.\n\nBy 2016, Bove suggested, Davidson was well-versed in the concept of squeezing celebrities such as Trump.\n\n\"And you did everything that you could to get as close to that line as possible in these negotiations without crossing it, right?\" Bove asked.\n\n\"I did everything I could to make sure my activities were lawful,\" Davidson replied.\n\n'WHAT DO WE GOT TO PAY FOR THIS?'\n\nThe prosecution's key witness, Cohen, has yet to testify -- and Trump might never at all -- but their voices were played in the courtroom in perhaps the most vivid piece of evidence so far.\n\nProsecutors played aloud a September 2016 recording that Cohen made of himself briefing the then-presidential candidate on a plan to buy McDougal's silence with a $150,000 payment. McDougal was prepared to come forward with her account of an extramarital affair with Trump, a disclosure Trump and his allies were determined to prevent in the final days of the election.\n\n\"What do we got to pay for this? One-fifty?\" Trump can be heard saying at one point.\n\nThey discuss whether the payment should be done with cash or check. Then the recording cuts out.\n\nThough the existence of the recording surfaced in the summer of 2018 and has long been known to the public, its disclosure to the jury was a dramatic moment meant to establish that the hush money payment was done with Trump's knowledge.\n\nHe appeared visibly irritated as the recording was played. Jurors seemed riveted.\n\nTHE 'JERK'\n\nThe recording was hardly the only time Cohen surfaced in court over the past week. When he did, it was generally in a negative light.\n\nDavidson said his introduction to Cohen came in 2011 when Davidson was told that he needed to return an angry call from Cohen over a blog post related to Daniels and Trump. Davidson said Cohen was described to him by Daniels' talent manager as \"some jerk\" who have been \"very, very aggressive and threatened to sue me.\"\n\nWhen Davidson called Cohen and introduced himself, \"I was just met with, like, a hustle barrage of insults and insinuations and allegations. That went on for quite a while.\"\n\nDavidson also recounted a memorable phone conversation with Cohen one month after the 2016 election in which the Trump attorney sounded \"depressed and despondent\" and complained about being passed over for a role in the new Trump administration.\n\n\"He said something to the effect of: 'Jesus Christ. Can you (expletive) believe I'm not going to Washington,'\" Davidson described Cohen as saying. \"'After everything I've done for that (expletive) guy. I can't believe I'm not going to Washington. I've saved that guy's (expletive) so many times, you don't even know.'\"\n\nThe uncharitable characterizations may help Trump's team in its efforts to undermine Cohen's credibility. But they could also help prosecutors distance themselves from Cohen, subtly indicating to jurors that he is not a teammate but rather someone who simply has information.\n\nTO JAIL A PRESIDENT\n\nA side issue throughout the trial is what to do about Trump's outside-of-court comments. He repeatedly has maligned witnesses and suggested bias on the jury -- all despite a judge's gag order meant to bar him from verbal tirades against key players in the case.\n\nTrump was assessed a $9,000 fine -- $1,000 for each of nine separate gag order violations that the judge identified. Prosecutors later requested an additional $4,000 penalty for what they said were additional breaches of the order.\n\nYet it remains unclear what, if anything, Judge Juan M. Merchan can do in the event of continued violations. Merchan floated the possibility of jail, an unprecedented outcome for a former American president. That also would risk inflaming Trump's base as he pursues the presidency and would further upend the 2024 White House race.\n\nTrump's attorneys insist he needs some leeway to be able to respond to relentless criticism, including from witnesses, and that his candidacy means he's the subject of nonstop news media coverage.\n\nMerchan seemed unpersuaded, but jail, for now at least, seems to be no one's desired outcome.\n\n\"Because each of these statements was made before the Court held the Defendant in contempt for violating this order nine previous times, and because we prefer to minimize disruptions to this proceeding, we are not yet seeking jail,\" prosecutor Chris Conroy said.\n\n\"But,\" he added, \"the Court's decision this past Tuesday will inform the approach we take to any future violations.\"", "source": {"uri": "eagletribune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Eagle-Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@eagletribune.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": {"uri": "2024-05-346560102", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "13:47:25", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T13:47:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T12:58:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/world/judge-fines-trump-us-1-000-for-contempt-threatens-jail-time-if-fines-aren-t-working-1.6874918", "title": "Judge fines Trump US$1,000 for contempt, threatens jail time if fines aren't working", "body": "A judge has fined former U.S. president Donald Trump $1,000 for contempt, threatening jail time if he violates a gag order again, saying fines aren't working.\n\nThis is a breaking news story. Check back for more information.\n\nOriginal copy follows.\n\nProsecutors in Donald Trump's hush money trial are moving deeper into his orbit following an inside-the-room account about the former president's reaction to a politically damaging recording that surfaced in the final weeks of the 2016 campaign.\n\nHope Hicks, a former White House official and for years a top aide, is by far the closest Trump associate to have taken the witness stand in the Manhattan trial.\n\nHer testimony Friday was designed to give jurors an insider's view of a chaotic and pivotal stretch in the campaign, when a 2005 recording showing Trump talking about grabbing women without their permission was made public and when he and his allies sought to prevent the release of other potentially embarrassing stories. That effort, prosecutors say, included hush money payments to a porn actor and Playboy model who both have said they had sexual encounters with Trump before he entered politics.\n\n\"I had a good sense to believe this was going to be a massive story and that it was going to dominate the news cycle for the next several days,\" Hicks said of the \"Access Hollywood\" recording, first revealed in an October 2016 Washington Post story. \"This was a damaging development.\"\n\nThe trial enters its third week of testimony Monday with prosecutors building toward their star witness, Michael Cohen, Trump's former lawyer and personal fixer who pleaded guilty to federal charges related to the hush money payments. Cohen is expected to undergo a bruising cross-examination from defense attorneys seeking to undermine his credibility with jurors.\n\nTrump faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records in connection with payments made to stifle potentially embarrassing stories. Prosecutors say Trump's company, the Trump Organization, reimbursed Cohen for payments to porn actor Stormy Daniels and gave Cohen bonuses and extra payments. Prosecutors allege that those transactions were falsely logged in company records as legal expenses.\n\nTrump has pleaded not guilty and denied sexual encounters with any of the women, as well as any wrongdoing.\n\nSo far, jurors have heard from witnesses including a tabloid magazine publisher and Trump friend who bought the rights to several sordid tales about Trump to prevent them from coming out and a Los Angeles lawyer who negotiated hush money deals on behalf of both Daniels and Playboy model Karen McDougal.\n\nTrump's lawyers have tried to chip away at the prosecution's theory of the case and the credibility of some witnesses. They've raised questions during cross-examinations about whether Trump was possibly a target of extortion, forced to arrange payouts to suppress harmful stories and spare his family embarrassment and pain. Prosecutors maintain the payments were about preserving his political viability as he sought the presidency.\n\nThe case is one of four Trump prosecutions and possibly the only one that will reach trial before the November election. Other felony indictments charge him with plotting to subvert the 2020 presidential election after he lost to Democrat Joe Biden and illegally hoarding classified documents after he left the White
