{"uri": "8113581424", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "10:15:53", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T10:15:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T10:15:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.startribune.com/the-latest-third-week-of-witness-testimony-in-trumps-hush-money-trial-is-set-to-kick-off/600363948/", "title": "The Latest | Third week of witness testimony in Trump's hush money trial is set to kick off", "body": "NEW YORK -- Witness testimony in Donald Trump's hush money trial is set to resume Monday morning, setting the stage for an even deeper dive into the events and people involved in what prosecutors have said was a scheme to influence the 2016 presidential election by buying and burying negative stories about the candidate.\n\nThe trial is in its 12th day.\n\nFormer Trump adviser Hope Hicks took the stand last week, recounting how Trump's campaign was turned upside-down following the leak of a video wherein he bragged about grabbing women without their permission.\n\nKeith Davidson, who represented porn actor Stormy Daniels and former Playboy model Karen McDougal in hush money negotiations, also took the stand. Davidson spent hours detailing his role in securing payouts for Daniels and McDougal in exchange for their silence about previous sexual encounters they said they had with Trump.\n\nTrump also faced a second contempt hearing over whether he had again violated his gag order over four more prospective violations. Judge Juan M. Merchan has not yet ruled on that sanctions request. Trump was fined $9,000 earlier in the week over gag order violations.\n\nOverall, prosecutors are setting the stage for pivotal testimony from Cohen, who paid Daniels $130,000 for her silence before he went to prison for the hush money scheme.\n\nTrump is accused of falsifying internal business records to cover up hush money payments -- including the payment to Daniels -- recording them instead as legal expenses.\n\nTrump has pleaded not guilty to 34 felony counts of falsifying business records.\n\nThe case is the first-ever criminal trial of a former U.S. president and the first of four prosecutions of Trump to reach a jury.\n\nCurrently:\n\n-- Hush money, catch and kill and more: Terms to know in Trump trial\n\n-- What Trump's gag order means in his hush money case\n\n-- Key players: Who's who at Donald Trump's hush money criminal trial\n\n-- The hush money case is just one of Trump's legal cases. See the others here\n\n-- Hulk Hogan, hurricanes and a blockbuster recording: A week in the Trump hush money trial\n\nWitness testimony in Donald Trump's criminal trial is entering its third week on Monday and it remains to be seen who will take the stand next.\n\nOver the past couple weeks, however, jurors have heard from a host of different people.\n\nFollowing a weeklong jury selection process that began mid-April, jurors heard first from former National Enquirer publisher David Pecker, who among other things explained his pledge to be the ''eyes and ears'' of Trump's 2016 presidential campaign.\n\nKeith Davidson, a lawyer who represented porn actor Stormy Daniels and former Playboy model Karen McDougal in hush money negotiations, also took the stand. And jurors heard from others such as a forensic analyst who examined Michael Cohen's phones and a paralegal with the Manhattan district attorney's office.\n\nAnd Former White House press secretary and ex-Trump adviser Hope Hicks painted a vivid picture of the chaos that unfolded after the ''Access Hollywood'' tape leaked and the Wall Street Journal ran a story about McDougal's hush money deal.\n\nThe defense cross-examined Hicks for roughly 20 minutes before court adjourned early last Friday.\n\nTHE WITNESS HEARD, BUT NOT YET SEEN\n\nAlthough an ensemble of different people have testified in Donald Trump's hush money case over the past two weeks, one pivotal witness has been frequently heard but not yet seen: Michael Cohen.\n\nJurors last week began hearing Cohen's words on audio recordings as prosecutors worked to directly tie Trump to payments to silence women with damaging claims about him before the 2016 election.\n\nJurors heard, in particular, a potentially crucial piece of evidence: a recording of Trump and Cohen, then his attorney, discussing a plan to pay off an ex-Playboy model who claimed to have an affair with Trump. The former president denies the affair.\n\nThey also heard a few witnesses recount their interactions with Cohen -- some pleasant and others far less so.\n\nIt's unclear when the prosecution's star witness will take the stand.\n\nTRUMP EXPECTED IN COURT AS TRIAL ENTERS 12TH DAY\n\nDonald Trump is expected to return to Manhattan court as his hush money trial enters its 12th day.\n\nLast week's proceedings saw a frenzy of witnesses take the stand, including former Trump adviser Hope Hicks and Keith Davidson, a lawyer who represented porn actor Stormy Daniels and former Playboy model Karen McDougal in hush money negotiations with Cohen and the National Enquirer.\n\nThe week also saw Trump fined $9,000 by Judge Juan M. Merchan for violating a gag order that bars the former president from speaking publicly about key witnesses, jurors and others in the case. A second contempt hearing was heard on Thursday over four more prospective violations, but Merchan did not immediately issue a decision.", "source": {"uri": "startribune.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8113918017", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "13:57:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T13:57:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T13:57:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.pbs.org/newshour/politics/what-to-know-as-trumps-hush-money-trial-enters-a-third-week", "title": "What to know as Trump's hush money trial enters a third week", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) -- Prosecutors in Donald Trump's hush money trial are moving deeper into his orbit following an inside-the-room account about the former president's reaction to a politically damaging recording that surfaced in the final weeks of the 2016 campaign.\n\nHope Hicks, a former White House official and for years a top aide, is by far the closest Trump associate to have taken the witness stand in the Manhattan trial.\n\nHer testimony Friday was designed to give jurors an insider's view of a chaotic and pivotal stretch in the campaign, when a 2005 recording showing Trump talking about grabbing women without their permission was made public and when he and his allies sought to prevent the release of other potentially embarrassing stories. That effort, prosecutors say, included hush money payments to a porn actor and Playboy model who both have said they had sexual encounters with Trump before he entered politics.\n\nREAD MORE: Former Trump adviser Hope Hicks testifies in hush money trial\n\n\"I had a good sense to believe this was going to be a massive story and that it was going to dominate the news cycle for the next several days,\" Hicks said of the \"Access Hollywood\" recording, first revealed in an October 2016 Washington Post story. \"This was a damaging development.\"\n\nThe trial enters its third week of testimony Monday with prosecutors building toward their star witness, Michael Cohen, Trump's former lawyer and personal fixer who pleaded guilty to federal charges related to the hush money payments. Cohen is expected to undergo a bruising cross-examination from defense attorneys seeking to undermine his credibility with jurors.\n\nTrump faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records in connection with payments made to stifle potentially embarrassing stories. Prosecutors say Trump's company, the Trump Organization, reimbursed Cohen for payments to porn actor Stormy Daniels and gave Cohen bonuses and extra payments. Prosecutors allege that those transactions were falsely logged in company records as legal expenses.\n\nTrump has pleaded not guilty and denied sexual encounters with any of the women, as well as any wrongdoing.\n\nSo far, jurors have heard from witnesses including a tabloid magazine publisher and Trump friend who bought the rights to several sordid tales about Trump to prevent them from coming out and a Los Angeles lawyer who negotiated hush money deals on behalf of both Daniels and Playboy model Karen McDougal.\n\nREAD MORE: Jurors in hush money trial hear recording of Trump discussing plan with Michael Cohen to pay off woman\n\nTrump's lawyers have tried to chip away at the prosecution's theory of the case and the credibility of some witnesses. They've raised questions during cross-examinations about whether Trump was possibly a target of extortion, forced to arrange payouts to suppress harmful stories and spare his family embarrassment and pain. Prosecutors maintain the payments were about preserving his political viability as he sought the presidency.\n\nThe case is one of four Trump prosecutions and possibly the only one that will reach trial before the November election. Other felony indictments charge him with plotting to subvert the 2020 presidential election after he lost to Democrat Joe Biden and illegally hoarding classified documents after he left the White House.\n\nTucker reported from Washington.", "source": {"uri": "pbs.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "PBS.org"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@pbs.org", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": true}, {"uri": "michael_r_sisak@pbs.org", "name": "Michael R. Davidson spent hours detailing his role in securing payouts for Daniels and McDougal in exchange for their silence about previous sexual encounters they said they had with Trump.\n\nTrump also faced a second contempt hearing over whether he had again violated his gag order over four more prospective violations. Judge Juan M. Merchan has not yet ruled on that sanctions request. Trump was fined $9,000 earlier in the week over gag order violations.\n\nOverall, prosecutors are setting the stage for pivotal testimony from Cohen, who paid Daniels $130,000 for her silence before he went to prison for the hush money scheme.\n\nTrump is accused of falsifying internal business records to cover up hush money payments -- including the payment to Daniels -- recording them instead as legal expenses.\n\nTrump has pleaded not guilty to 34 felony counts of falsifying business records.\n\nThe case is the first-ever criminal trial of a former U.S. president and the first of four prosecutions of Trump to reach a jury.\n\nCurrently:\n\n-- Hush money, catch and kill and more: Terms to know in Trump trial\n\n-- What Trump's gag order means in his hush money case\n\n-- Key players: Who's who at Donald Trump's hush money criminal trial\n\n-- The hush money case is just one of Trump's legal cases. And jurors heard from others such as a forensic analyst who examined Michael Cohen's phones and a paralegal with the Manhattan district attorney's office.\n\nAnd Former White House press secretary and ex-Trump adviser Hope Hicks painted a vivid picture of the chaos that unfolded after the \"Access Hollywood\" tape leaked and the Wall Street Journal ran a story about McDougal's hush money deal.\n\nThe defense cross-examined Hicks for roughly 20 minutes before court adjourned early last Friday.\n\nTHE WITNESS HEARD, BUT NOT YET SEEN\n\nAlthough an ensemble of different people have testified in Donald Trump's hush money case over the past two weeks, one pivotal witness has been frequently heard but not yet seen: Michael Cohen.\n\nJurors last week began hearing Cohen's words on audio recordings as prosecutors worked to directly tie Trump to payments to silence women with damaging claims about him before the 2016 election.\n\nJurors heard, in particular, a potentially crucial piece of evidence: a recording of Trump and Cohen, then his attorney, discussing a plan to pay off an ex-Playboy model who claimed to have an affair with Trump. The former president denies the affair.\n\nThey also heard a few witnesses recount their interactions with Cohen -- some pleasant and others far less so.\n\nIt's unclear when the prosecution's star witness will take the stand.\n\nTRUMP EXPECTED IN COURT AS TRIAL ENTERS 12TH DAY\n\nDonald Trump is expected to return to Manhattan court as his hush money trial enters its 12th day.\n\nLast week's proceedings saw a frenzy of witnesses take the stand, including former Trump adviser Hope Hicks and Keith Davidson, a lawyer who represented porn actor Stormy Daniels and former Playboy model Karen McDougal in hush money negotiations with Cohen and the National Enquirer.\n\nThe week also saw Trump fined $9,000 by Judge Juan M. {"uri": "8113598474", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "10:27:51", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T10:27:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T10:27:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13386921/The-Latest--Third-week-witness-testimony-Trumps-hush-money-trial-set-kick-off.html", "title": "The Latest | Third week of witness testimony in Trump's hush money...", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) - Witness testimony in Donald Trump's hush money trial is set to resume Monday morning, setting the stage for an even deeper dive into the events and people involved in what prosecutors have said was a scheme to influence the 2016 presidential election by buying and burying negative stories about the candidate.\n\nThe trial is in its 12th day.\n\nFormer Trump adviser Hope Hicks took the stand last week, recounting how Trump's campaign was turned upside-down following the leak of a video wherein he bragged about grabbing women without their permission.\n\nKeith Davidson, who represented porn actor Stormy Daniels and former Playboy model Karen McDougal in hush money negotiations, also took the stand. Davidson spent hours detailing his role in securing payouts for Daniels and McDougal in exchange for their silence about previous sexual encounters they said they had with Trump.\n\nTrump also faced a second contempt hearing over whether he had again violated his gag order over four more prospective violations. Judge Juan M. Merchan has not yet ruled on that sanctions request. Trump was fined $9,000 earlier in the week over gag order violations.\n\nOverall, prosecutors are setting the stage for pivotal testimony from Cohen, who paid Daniels $130,000 for her silence before he went to prison for the hush money scheme.\n\nFormer President Donald Trump speaks to media as he returns to his trial at the Manhattan Criminal Court, Friday, May 3, 2024, in New York. (Charly Triballeau/Pool Photo via AP)\n\nTrump is accused of falsifying internal business records to cover up hush money payments - including the payment to Daniels - recording them instead as legal expenses.\n\nTrump has pleaded not guilty to 34 felony counts of falsifying business records.\n\nThe case is the first-ever criminal trial of a former U.S. president and the first of four prosecutions of Trump to reach a jury.\n\nCurrently:\n\n- Hush money, catch and kill and more: Terms to know in Trump trial\n\n- What Trump\u00b4s gag order means in his hush money case\n\n- Key players: Who\u00b4s who at Donald Trump\u00b4s hush money criminal trial\n\n- The hush money case is just one of Trump\u00b4s legal cases. See the others here\n\n- Hulk Hogan, hurricanes and a blockbuster recording: A week in the Trump hush money trial\n\nHere's the latest:\n\nWitness testimony in Donald Trump's criminal trial is entering its third week on Monday and it remains to be seen who will take the stand next.\n\nOver the past couple weeks, however, jurors have heard from a host of different people.\n\nFollowing a weeklong jury selection process that began mid-April, jurors heard first from former National Enquirer publisher David Pecker, who among other things explained his pledge to be the \"eyes and ears\" of Trump's 2016 presidential campaign.\n\nKeith Davidson, a lawyer who represented porn actor Stormy Daniels and former Playboy model Karen McDougal in hush money negotiations, also took the stand. And jurors heard from others such as a forensic analyst who examined Michael Cohen's phones and a paralegal with the Manhattan district attorney's office.\n\nAnd Former White House press secretary and ex-Trump adviser Hope Hicks painted a vivid picture of the chaos that unfolded after the \"Access Hollywood\" tape leaked and the Wall Street Journal ran a story about McDougal's hush money deal.\n\nThe defense cross-examined Hicks for roughly 20 minutes before court adjourned early last Friday.\n\nAlthough an ensemble of different people have testified in Donald Trump's hush money case over the past two weeks, one pivotal witness has been frequently heard but not yet seen: Michael Cohen.\n\nJurors last week began hearing Cohen\u00b4s words on audio recordings as prosecutors worked to directly tie Trump to payments to silence women with damaging claims about him before the 2016 election.\n\nJurors heard, in particular, a potentially crucial piece of evidence: a recording of Trump and Cohen, then his attorney, discussing a plan to pay off an ex-Playboy model who claimed to have an affair with Trump. The former president denies the affair.\n\nThey also heard a few witnesses recount their interactions with Cohen - some pleasant and others far less so.\n\nIt's unclear when the prosecution's star witness will take the stand.\n\nDonald Trump is expected to return to Manhattan court as his hush money trial enters its 12th day.\n\nLast week's proceedings saw a frenzy of witnesses take the stand, including former Trump adviser Hope Hicks and Keith Davidson, a lawyer who represented porn actor Stormy Daniels and former Playboy model Karen McDougal in hush money negotiations with Cohen and the National Enquirer.\n\nThe week also saw Trump fined $9,000 by Judge Juan M. Merchan for violating a gag order that bars the former president from speaking publicly about key witnesses, jurors and others in the case. A second contempt hearing was heard on Thursday over four more prospective violations, but Merchan did not immediately issue a decision.\n\nFormer President Donald Trump appears at Manhattan criminal court before his trial in New York, Friday,, May 3, 2024.(Charly Triballeau/Pool Photo via AP)\n\nFormer President Donald Trump returns to his trial at the Manhattan Criminal Court, Friday, May 3, 2024, in New York. "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9540922", "eventUri": "eng-9540922", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.1372549019607843, "wgt": 197, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-05-346628431", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "14:48:38", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T14:48:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T14:29:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/trump-fined-1-000-for-gag-order-violation-in-hush-money-case-as-judge-warns/article_c1524111-a060-5060-afb0-9ef9cf0265c0.html", "title": "Trump fined $1,000 for gag order violation in hush money case as judge warns of possible jail time", "body": "By MICHAEL R. SISAK, JENNIFER PELTZ, ERIC TUCKER and JAKE OFFENHARTZ - Associated Press\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- The judge presiding over Donald Trump's hush money trial fined him $1,000 on Monday for violating his gag order once again and sternly warned the former president that additional violations could result in jail time.\n\nThe fine marks the second time since the trial began last month that Trump has been sanctioned for violating the gag order, which bars him from making incendiary comments about jurors, witnesses and other people closely connected to the case. He was fined $9,000 last week, $1,000 for each of nine violations.\n\n\"It appears that the $1,000 fines are not serving as a deterrent. Therefore going forward, this court will have to consider a jail sanction,\" Judge Juan M. Merchan said before jurors were brought into the courtroom. Trump's statements, the judge added, \"threaten to interfere with the fair administration of justice and constitute a direct attack on the rule of law. I cannot allow that to continue.\"\n\nThe violation in this case stems from an April 22 interview with television channel Real America's Voice in which Trump criticized the speed at which the jury was picked and claimed it was stacked with Democrats.\n\n\"That jury was picked so fast -- 95% Democrats,\" Trump said at the time. \"The area's mostly all Democrat. You think of it as a, just a purely Democrat area. It's a very unfair situation that I can tell you.\"\n\nTrump sat forward in his seat, glowering at the judge as he handed down the ruling. When the judge finished speaking, Trump shook his head twice and crossed his arms.\n\nYet even as Merchan warned of jail time in his most pointed and direct admonition, he also made clear his reservations about a step that he described as a \"last resort.\"\n\n\"The last thing I want to do is put you in jail,\" Merchan said. \"You are the former president of the United States and possibly the next president as well. There are many reasons why incarceration is truly a last resort for me. To take that step would be disruptive to these proceedings.\"\n\nMeanwhile, testimony resumed Monday with prosecutors calling to the stand Jeffrey McConney, the former Trump Organization controller.\n\nHe retired from the company last year after 36 years after being granted immunity to testify for the prosecution at the Trump Organization's New York criminal tax fraud trial, where he admitted breaking the law to help fellow executives avoid taxes on company-paid perks. The company was convicted and is appealing.\n\nThe testimony follows an inside-the-room account given to jurors Friday about Trump's reaction to a politically damaging recording that surfaced in the final weeks of the 2016 campaign.\n\nHope Hicks, a former White House official and for years a top aide, was by far the closest Trump associate to have taken the witness stand in the Manhattan trial.\n\nHer testimony was designed to give jurors an insider's view of a chaotic and pivotal stretch in the campaign, when a 2005 recording showing Trump talking about grabbing women sexually without their permission was made public and when he and his allies sought to prevent the release of other potentially embarrassing stories.\n\nThat effort, prosecutors say, included hush money payments to a porn actor and Playboy model who both have said they had sexual encounters with Trump before he entered politics.\n\n\"I had a good sense to believe this was going to be a massive story and that it was going to dominate the news cycle for the next several days,\" Hicks said of the \"Access Hollywood\" recording, first revealed in an October 2016 Washington Post story. \"This was a damaging development.\"\n\nThe trial entered its third week of testimony Monday with prosecutors building toward their star witness, Michael Cohen, Trump's former lawyer and personal fixer who pleaded guilty to federal charges related to the hush money payments. Cohen is expected to undergo a bruising cross-examination from defense attorneys seeking to undermine his credibility with jurors.\n\nTrump faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records in connection with payments made to stifle potentially embarrassing stories. Prosecutors say Trump's company, the Trump Organization, reimbursed Cohen for payments to porn actor Stormy Daniels and gave Cohen bonuses and extra payments. Prosecutors allege that those transactions were falsely logged in company records as legal expenses.\n\nTrump has pleaded not guilty and denied sexual encounters with any of the women, as well as any wrongdoing.\n\nSo far, jurors have heard from witnesses including a tabloid magazine publisher and Trump friend who bought the rights to several sordid tales about Trump to prevent them from coming out and a Los Angeles lawyer who negotiated hush money deals on behalf of both Daniels and Playboy model Karen McDougal.\n\nTrump's lawyers have tried to chip away at the prosecution's theory of the case and the credibility of some witnesses. They've raised questions during cross-examinations about whether Trump was possibly a target of extortion, forced to arrange payouts to suppress harmful stories and spare his family embarrassment and pain. Prosecutors maintain the payments were about preserving his political viability as he sought the presidency.\n\nThe case is one of four Trump prosecutions and possibly the only one that will reach trial before the November election. Other felony indictments charge him with plotting to subvert the 2020 presidential election after he lost to Democrat Joe Biden and illegally hoarding classified documents after he left the White House.\n\nTucker reported from Washington.\n\nMore from this section\n\nStack Sports launches Stack Rewards to Save Youth Sports Families $100M Striking deals to end campus protests, some colleges invite discussion of their investments", "source": {"uri": "kulr8.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KULR-8 Local News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@kulr8.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "michael_r_sisak@kulr8.com", "name": "Michael R. Additional sanctions could await the presumptive Republican presidential nominee.\n\nHope Hicks, a former Trump confidant who played a central role in his orbit for years, detailed a defining moment from the 2016 campaign: The Washington Post leaked a 2005 Access Hollywood recording in which Trump bragged about grabbing women's genitals without their permission.\n\nHicks admitted to being worried, very worried, when a reporter asked him for comment before breaking the story.\n\nI had a good feeling of believing that this was going to be a massive story and that it was going to dominate the news cycle over the next few days, Hicks said. This was a damaging development.\n\nThe recording, made public just days before a debate with Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton, is relevant to the case because prosecutors say it helps explain the frenzied efforts by Trump and his allies in the final weeks of campaign to try to suppress any new damaging stories that might arise. .\n\nFILE - Hope Hicks, former White House communications director, arrives to meet with the House Intelligence Committee, at the Capitol in Washington, February 27, 2018. (AP Photo/J. Scott Applewhite, File)\n\nIn fact, following the release of the tapes, Hicks said he asked Michael Cohen, then Trump's lawyer and personal fixer, to track down a rumor about another potentially damaging recording. No such tape existed anyway, Hicks said, but he sort of looked it up for me.\n\nRegardless, the immediate impact of the Access Hollywood story was so intense, Hicks recalls, that it distracted from a perfect storm. Hurricane Matthew was dominating the news cycle when Hicks was contacted about the upcoming story. It didn't last long.\n\nDid the Access Hollywood tape make the hurricane disappear from the news? \" asked prosecutor Matthew Colangelo.\n\nTrump may be a criminal defendant, but a piece of his defense emerged last week when one of his lawyers suggested that Trump might actually have been a victim.\n\nLawyer Emil Bove suggested during a particularly tense cross-examination that his client had indeed been targeted for extortion by Keith Davidson, a crucial witness and the lawyer who negotiated hush money deals for two women, porn actor Stormy Daniels and Playboy model Karen McDougal, claiming to have had sex with Trump. Trump denies it.\n\nBove cited a group of celebrities who he said had been forced over the years to pay huge sums to Davidson's clients to remove harmful videos or stories. Among them was actor Charlie Sheen, from whom Bove, according to Davidson, had extorted money; Davidson disputed the word excerpt, but said he had been involved in valid settlements with Sheen.\n\nEmil Bove, attorney for former President Donald Trump, sits in the courtroom at Manhattan Criminal Court in New York, Friday, May 3, 2024. (Jeenah Moon/Pool Photo via AP)\n\nDavidson also acknowledges that he was investigated by the FBI, but never charged, for allegedly trying to extort Hogan to prevent the release of the professional wrestling stars' sex tape.\n\nIn 2016, Bove suggested, Davidson was familiar with the concept of trashing celebrities such as Trump.\n\nAnd you've done everything you can to get as close to that line in these negotiations as possible without crossing it, right? \" asked Bov\u00e9.\n\nI did everything I could to make sure my activities were legal, Davidson responded.\n\nWhat do we have to pay for that?\n\nThe prosecution's key witness, Cohen, has yet to testify and Trump may never do so, but their voices were heard in the courtroom in perhaps the most striking piece of evidence yet now.\n\nProsecutors played loudly a September 2016 recording Cohen made of himself informing the then-presidential candidate of a plan to buy McDougal's silence with a $150,000 payment. McDougal was ready to reveal her account of an extramarital affair with Trump, a revelation that Trump and his allies were determined to prevent in the final days of the election.\n\nWhat are we going to pay for this? One hour fifty? Trump can be heard saying at one point.\n\nFILE - Michael Cohen arrives at the New York Supreme Court on October 25, 2023, in New York. (AP Photo/Yuki Iwamura, file)\n\nThey discuss whether payment should be made in cash or by check. Then the recording stops.\n\nAlthough the existence of the recording surfaced in the summer of 2018 and had long been publicly known, its disclosure to the jury was a dramatic moment intended to establish that the secret payment was made with Trump's knowledge.\n\nHe seemed visibly irritated as the recording played. The jurors seemed fascinated.\n\nTHE JERK\n\nThe recording wasn't the only time Cohen surfaced in court over the past week. When he did, it was usually in a negative light.\n\nDavidson said his introduction to Cohen came in 2011, when he was told he had to respond to an angry call from Cohen about a blog post linked to Daniels and Trump. Davidson said that Cohen was described to him by Daniels' talent manager as a jerk who had been very, very aggressive and had threatened to sue me.\n\nWhen Davidson called Cohen and introduced himself, I was met with a barrage of insults, innuendoes and allegations. This lasted quite a while.\n\nDavidson also recounted a memorable phone conversation with Cohen a month after the 2016 election, during which the Trump lawyer seemed depressed and discouraged and complained about being passed over for a role in the new Trump administration.\n\nHe said something like: Jesus Christ. Can you (exhaustive) believe I'm not going to Washington, Davidson said in describing Cohen. After everything I did for that (expletive) guy. I can't believe I'm not going to Washington. I've saved these guys (expletive) so many times you don't even know it.\n\nThe uncharitable characterizations could help Trump's team in its efforts to undermine Cohen's credibility. But they could also help prosecutors distance themselves from Cohen, subtly telling jurors that he is not a teammate but rather someone who simply has information.\n\nTO GET A PRESIDENT\n\nA side issue throughout the trial is what to do about Trump's comments outside of court. He repeatedly slandered witnesses and suggested jury bias, all despite a judge's order of silence intended to bar him from any verbal tirades against key players in the case.\n\nTrump was fined $9,000 ($1,000) for each of nine separate violations of the silence order identified by the judge. Prosecutors then sought an additional $4,000 fine for what they said were additional violations of the order.\n\nStill, it's unclear what Judge Juan M. Merchan can do about continued violations. Merchan raised the possibility of prison time, an unprecedented outcome for a former U.S. president. It would also risk inflaming Trump's base as he runs for president and further upend the race for the White House in 2024.\n\nFormer President Donald Trump, center, speaks with defense attorney Emil Bove, left, before the start of the trial in Manhattan Criminal Court, Friday, May 3, 2024 in New York. (Mark Peterson/Pool photo via AP)\n\nTrump's lawyers insist he needs some leeway to respond to relentless criticism, including from witnesses, and that his candidacy means he is subject to scrutiny. continued media coverage.\n\nMerchan didn't seem convinced, but prison, at least for now, doesn't seem to be the outcome anyone wants.\n\nBecause each of these statements was made before the Court found the defendant in contempt for violating this order on nine occasions, and because we prefer to minimize the disruption of this proceeding, we are not yet seeking prison , said prosecutor Chris Conroy.\n\nBut, he added, last Tuesday's court decision will inform the approach we take to any future violations.\n\nWhat Are The Main Benefits Of Comparing Car Insurance Quotes Online", "source": {"uri": "8113945744", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "14:15:35", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T14:15:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T14:15:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://newsadvance.com/news/nation-world/donald-trump-hush-money-gag-order-violation/article_bbd3de63-2bc7-520e-a440-04bfc9a47750.html", "title": "Trump fined $1,000 for gag order violation in hush money case as judge warns of possible jail time", "body": "NEW YORK -- The judge presiding over Donald Trump's hush money trial has fined him $1,000 for violating his gag order and sternly warned the former president that additional violation could result in jail time.\n\nThe fine marks the second sanction for Trump for inflammatory comments about witnesses since the start of the trial last month. He was fined $9,000 last week for nine violations.\n\nJudge Juan M. Merchan warned Monday that additional gag order violations could potentially result in jail time, though he said that was \"the last thing I want to do.\"\n\nProsecutors in Trump's hush money trial are moving deeper into his orbit following an inside-the-room account about the former president's reaction to a politically damaging recording that surfaced in the final weeks of the 2016 campaign.\n\nHope Hicks, a former White House official and for years a top aide, is by far the closest Trump associate to have taken the witness stand in the Manhattan trial.\n\nHer testimony Friday was designed to give jurors an insider's view of a chaotic and pivotal stretch in the campaign, when a 2005 recording showing Trump talking about grabbing women without their permission was made public and when he and his allies sought to prevent the release of other potentially embarrassing stories. That effort, prosecutors say, included hush money payments to a porn actor and Playboy model who both have said they had sexual encounters with Trump before he entered politics.\n\n\"I had a good sense to believe this was going to be a massive story and that it was going to dominate the news cycle for the next several days,\" Hicks said of the \"Access Hollywood\" recording, first revealed in an October 2016 Washington Post story. \"This was a damaging development.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThe trial enters its third week of testimony Monday with prosecutors building toward their star witness, Michael Cohen, Trump's former lawyer and personal fixer who pleaded guilty to federal charges related to the hush money payments. Cohen is expected to undergo a bruising cross-examination from defense attorneys seeking to undermine his credibility with jurors.\n\nTrump faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records in connection with payments made to stifle potentially embarrassing stories. Prosecutors say Trump's company, the Trump Organization, reimbursed Cohen for payments to porn actor Stormy Daniels and gave Cohen bonuses and extra payments. Prosecutors allege that those transactions were falsely logged in company records as legal expenses.\n\nTrump has pleaded not guilty and denied sexual encounters with any of the women, as well as any wrongdoing.\n\nSo far, jurors have heard from witnesses including a tabloid magazine publisher and Trump friend who bought the rights to several sordid tales about Trump to prevent them from coming out and a Los Angeles lawyer who negotiated hush money deals on behalf of both Daniels and Playboy model Karen McDougal.\n\nTrump's lawyers have tried to chip away at the prosecution's theory of the case and the credibility of some witnesses. They've raised questions during cross-examinations about whether Trump was possibly a target of extortion, forced to arrange payouts to suppress harmful stories and spare his family embarrassment and pain. Prosecutors maintain the payments were about preserving his political viability as he sought the presidency.\n\nThe case is one of four Trump prosecutions and possibly the only one that will reach trial before the November election. Other felony indictments charge him with plotting to subvert the 2020 presidential election after he lost to Democrat Joe Biden and illegally hoarding classified documents after he left the White House.\n\n____\n\nTucker reported from Washington.\n\nTags Wire Dcc Lee-national Law Politics Criminal Law Trade Business The Economy Legislation Crime Be the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.", "source": {"uri": "newsadvance.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NewsAdvance.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": "eric_tucker@newsadvance.com", "name": "Eric Tucker", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "michael_r_sisak@newsadvance.com", "name": "Michael R. {"uri": "8113960786", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "14:25:09", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T14:25:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T14:24:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.pressherald.com/2024/05/06/judge-warns-trump-he-could-be-jailed-for-violating-gag-order-again/", "title": "Judge warns Trump he could be jailed for violating gag order again", "body": "Former President Donald Trump appears at Manhattan criminal court before his trial in New York, Friday, May 3, 2024. Charly Triballeau/Pool Photo via AP\n\nNEW YORK -- The judge presiding over Donald Trump's hush money trial fined him $1,000 on Monday for violating his gag order once again and sternly warned the former president that additional violations could result in jail time.\n\nThe fine marks the second time since the trial began last month that Trump has been sanctioned for violating the gag order, which bars him from making incendiary comments about jurors, witnesses and other people closely connected to the case. He was fined $9,000 last week, $1,000 for each of nine violations.\n\nThe violation in this case stems from an April 22 interview in which he criticized the speed at which the jury was picked and claimed it was stacked with Democrats.\n\n\"It appears that the $1,000 fines are not serving as a deterrent. Therefore going forward, this court will have to consider a jail sanction,\" Judge Juan Merchan said. Trump's statements, the judge continued, \"threaten to interfere with the fair administration of justice and constitute a direct attack on the rule of law. I cannot allow that to continue.\"\n\nBut he also expressed reservations about the idea of putting Trump in jail, calling it \"the last thing I want to do.\"\n\n\"You are the former president of the United States and possibly the next president as well. There are many reasons why incarceration is truly a last resort for me. To take that step would be disruptive to these proceedings,\" Merchan said.\n\nAdvertisement Related Trump escalates attacks on prosecutors, says Democrats run 'a Gestapo administration'\n\nMeanwhile, testimony resumed Monday with prosecutors moving deeper into Trump's orbit following an inside-the-room account about the former president's reaction to a politically damaging recording that surfaced in the final weeks of the 2016 campaign.\n\nHope Hicks, a former White House official and for years a top aide, is by far the closest Trump associate to have taken the witness stand in the Manhattan trial.\n\nHer testimony Friday was designed to give jurors an insider's view of a chaotic and pivotal stretch in the campaign, when a 2005 recording showing Trump talking about grabbing women sexually without their permission was made public and when he and his allies sought to prevent the release of other potentially embarrassing stories.\n\nRelated Former Trump advisor Hope Hicks testifies at hush money trial\n\nThat effort, prosecutors say, included hush money payments to a porn actor and Playboy model who both have said they had sexual encounters with Trump before he entered politics.\n\n\"I had a good sense to believe this was going to be a massive story and that it was going to dominate the news cycle for the next several days,\" Hicks said of the \"Access Hollywood\" recording, first revealed in an October 2016 Washington Post story. \"This was a damaging development.\"\n\nThe trial entered its third week of testimony Monday with prosecutors building toward their star witness, Michael Cohen, Trump's former lawyer and personal fixer who pleaded guilty to federal charges related to the hush money payments. Cohen is expected to undergo a bruising cross-examination from defense attorneys seeking to undermine his credibility with jurors.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nTrump faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records in connection with payments made to stifle potentially embarrassing stories. Prosecutors say Trump's company, the Trump Organization, reimbursed Cohen for payments to porn actor Stormy Daniels and gave Cohen bonuses and extra payments. Prosecutors allege that those transactions were falsely logged in company records as legal expenses.\n\nTrump has pleaded not guilty and denied sexual encounters with any of the women, as well as any wrongdoing.\n\nSo far, jurors have heard from witnesses including a tabloid magazine publisher and Trump friend who bought the rights to several sordid tales about Trump to prevent them from coming out and a Los Angeles lawyer who negotiated hush money deals on behalf of both Daniels and Playboy model Karen McDougal.\n\nTrump's lawyers have tried to chip away at the prosecution's theory of the case and the credibility of some witnesses. They've raised questions during cross-examinations about whether Trump was possibly a target of extortion, forced to arrange payouts to suppress harmful stories and spare his family embarrassment and pain. Prosecutors maintain the payments were about preserving his political viability as he sought the presidency.\n\nThe case is one of four Trump prosecutions and possibly the only one that will reach trial before the November election. Other felony indictments charge him with plotting to subvert the 2020 presidential election after he lost to Democrat Joe Biden and illegally hoarding classified documents after he left the White House.\n\nCopy the Story Link Related Headlines Trump escalates attacks on prosecutors, says Democrats run 'a Gestapo administration' Former Trump advisor Hope Hicks testifies at hush money trial Hush money trial judge raises threat of jail as he finds Trump violated gag order, fines him $9,000\n\nInvalid username/password.\n\nPlease check your email to confirm and complete your registration.\n\nCreate a commenting profile by providing an email address, password and display name. {"uri": "2024-05-346558766", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "13:45:59", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T13:45:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T12:35:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.channel3000.com/news/prosecutors-move-deeper-into-trumps-orbit-as-testimony-in-hush-money-trial-enters-a-third/article_ff617292-e0b4-5f7d-bf60-333bd258ccdd.html", "title": "Prosecutors move deeper into Trump's orbit as testimony in hush money trial enters a third week", "body": "By MICHAEL R. SISAK, JENNIFER PELTZ, ERIC TUCKER and JAKE OFFENHARTZ - Associated Press\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- Prosecutors in Donald Trump's hush money trial are moving deeper into his orbit following an inside-the-room account about the former president's reaction to a politically damaging recording that surfaced in the final weeks of the 2016 campaign.\n\nHope Hicks, a former White House official and for years a top aide, is by far the closest Trump associate to have taken the witness stand in the Manhattan trial.\n\nHer testimony Friday was designed to give jurors an insider's view of a chaotic and pivotal stretch in the campaign, when a 2005 recording showing Trump talking about grabbing women without their permission was made public and when he and his allies sought to prevent the release of other potentially embarrassing stories. That effort, prosecutors say, included hush money payments to a porn actor and Playboy model who both have said they had sexual encounters with Trump before he entered politics.\n\n\"I had a good sense to believe this was going to be a massive story and that it was going to dominate the news cycle for the next several days,\" Hicks said of the \"Access Hollywood\" recording, first revealed in an October 2016 Washington Post story. \"This was a damaging development.\"\n\nThe trial enters its third week of testimony Monday with prosecutors building toward their star witness, Michael Cohen, Trump's former lawyer and personal fixer who pleaded guilty to federal charges related to the hush money payments. Cohen is expected to undergo a bruising cross-examination from defense attorneys seeking to undermine his credibility with jurors.\n\nTrump faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records in connection with payments made to stifle potentially embarrassing stories. Prosecutors say Trump's company, the Trump Organization, reimbursed Cohen for payments to porn actor Stormy Daniels and gave Cohen bonuses and extra payments. Prosecutors allege that those transactions were falsely logged in company records as legal expenses.\n\nTrump has pleaded not guilty and denied sexual encounters with any of the women, as well as any wrongdoing.\n\nSo far, jurors have heard from witnesses including a tabloid magazine publisher and Trump friend who bought the rights to several sordid tales about Trump to prevent them from coming out and a Los Angeles lawyer who negotiated hush money deals on behalf of both Daniels and Playboy model Karen McDougal.\n\nTrump's lawyers have tried to chip away at the prosecution's theory of the case and the credibility of some witnesses. They've raised questions during cross-examinations about whether Trump was possibly a target of extortion, forced to arrange payouts to suppress harmful stories and spare his family embarrassment and pain. Prosecutors maintain the payments were about preserving his political viability as he sought the presidency.\n\nThe case is one of four Trump prosecutions and possibly the only one that will reach trial before the November election. Other felony indictments charge him with plotting to subvert the 2020 presidential election after he lost to Democrat Joe Biden and illegally hoarding classified documents after he left the White House.\n\nTucker reported from Washington.\n\nCOPYRIGHT 2024 BY CHANNEL 3000. {"uri": "8113935047", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "14:08:47", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T14:08:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T14:08:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://lethbridgenewsnow.com/2024/05/06/the-latest-judge-fines-trump-1k-for-contempt-threatens-jail-time-if-he-violates-gag-order-again/", "title": "The Latest | Judge fines Trump $1K for contempt, threatens jail time if he violates gag order again", "body": "Witness testimony was set to resume following Merchan's ruling, setting the stage for an even deeper dive into the events and people involved in what prosecutors have said was a scheme to influence the 2016 presidential election by buying and burying negative stories about the then-candidate.\n\nFormer Trump adviser Hope Hicks took the stand last week, recounting how Trump's campaign was turned upside-down following the leak of a video wherein he bragged about grabbing women without their permission.\n\nKeith Davidson, who represented porn actor Stormy Daniels and former Playboy model Karen McDougal in hush money negotiations, also took the stand. Davidson spent hours detailing his role in securing payouts for Daniels and McDougal in exchange for their silence about previous sexual encounters they said they had with Trump.\n\nOverall, prosecutors are setting the stage for pivotal testimony from Michael Cohen, who paid Daniels $130,000 for her silence before he went to prison for the hush money scheme.\n\nTrump is accused of falsifying internal business records to cover up hush money payments -- including the payment to Daniels -- recording them instead as legal expenses.\n\nTrump has pleaded not guilty to 34 felony counts of falsifying business records.\n\nThe case is the first-ever criminal trial of a former U.S. president and the first of four prosecutions of Trump to reach a jury.\n\n-- Hulk Hogan, hurricanes and a blockbuster recording: A week in the Trump hush money trial\n\nThe judge in Donald Trump's hush money case found on Monday that Donald Trump had violated his gag order with comments he gave to a program called \"Just the News No Noise\" on April 22, which is broadcast on Real America's Voice.\n\nOn the program, the former president criticized the speed at which the jury was picked and claimed it was stacked with Democrats. \"The jury was picked so fast. 95 percent Democrats. The area's mostly all Democrat,\" he is quoted as saying.\n\nIn his ruling, Judge Juan M. Merchan said the comments \"not only called into question the integrity, and therefore the legitimacy of these proceedings, but again raised the specter of fear for the safety of the jurors and of their loved ones.\"\n\nThe gag order bars Trump from making comments about the jurors, key witnesses and some others connected to the criminal trial.\n\nJUDGE FINES TRUMP AGAIN FOR CONTEMPT, THREATENS JAIL TIME\n\nThe judge presiding over former President Donald Trump's hush money trial has fined him an additional $1,000 for again violating a gag order barring him from making inflammatory comments about witnesses and jurors.\n\nJudge Juan M. Merchan warned on Monday that additional gag order violations could potentially result in jail time.\n\n\"The last thing I want to do is put you in jail. You are the former president of the United States and possibly the next president as well,\" Merchan said. \"There are many reasons why incarceration is truly a last resort for me. To take that step would be disruptive to these proceedings.\"\n\nTrump sat forward in his seat, glowering at the judge as he handed down the ruling. Once the judge finished speaking, Trump shook his head twice and crossed his arms.\n\nProsecutors had accused Trump of four violations, but the judge only concurred with one.\n\nThe judge had previously fined Trump $9,000 for nine earlier violations in posts on Truth Social and his website.\n\nTRUMP TALKS COLUMBIA COMMENCEMENT CANCELLATION BEFORE COURT\n\nBefore heading into the courtroom Monday morning, Donald Trump spoke to reporters, relaying familiar complaints about the fairness of the trial, the judge and the gag order that stops him commenting on witnesses and jurors.\n\nHe also noted the breaking news that Columbia University canceled its main commencement following weeks of pro-Palestinian protests.\n\nDonald Trump has arrived at the courthouse in lower Manhattan as witness testimony in his hush money trial enters its third week.\n\nWitness testimony in Donald Trump's criminal trial is entering its third week on Monday and it remains to be seen who will take the stand next.\n\nOver the past couple weeks, jurors have heard from a host of different people.\n\nFollowing a weeklong jury selection process that began mid-April, jurors heard first from former National Enquirer publisher David Pecker, who among other things explained his pledge to be the \"eyes and ears\" of Trump's 2016 presidential campaign.\n\nKeith Davidson, a lawyer who represented porn actor Stormy Daniels and former Playboy model Karen McDougal in hush money negotiations, also took the stand. And jurors heard from others such as a forensic analyst who examined Michael Cohen's phones and a paralegal with the Manhattan district attorney's office.\n\nFormer White House press secretary and ex-Trump adviser Hope Hicks on Friday painted a vivid picture of the chaos that unfolded after the \"Access Hollywood\" tape leaked and the Wall Street Journal ran a story about McDougal's hush money deal.\n\nThe defense cross-examined Hicks for roughly 20 minutes before court adjourned early last Friday.\n\nTHE WITNESS HEARD, BUT NOT YET SEEN\n\nAlthough an ensemble of different people have testified in Donald Trump's hush money case over the past two weeks, one pivotal witness has been frequently heard but not yet seen: Michael Cohen, Trump's former lawyer and personal fixer.\n\nJurors last week began hearing Cohen's words on audio recordings as prosecutors worked to directly tie Trump to payments to silence women with damaging claims about him before the 2016 election.\n\nJurors heard, in particular, a potentially crucial piece of evidence: a recording of Trump and Cohen, then his attorney, discussing a plan to pay off an ex-Playboy model who claimed to have an affair with Trump. The former president denies the affair.\n\nThey also heard a few witnesses recount their interactions with Cohen -- some pleasant and others far less so.\n\nIt's unclear when the prosecution's star witness will take the stand.\n\nTRUMP EXPECTED IN COURT AS TRIAL ENTERS 12TH DAY\n\nDonald Trump is expected to return to Manhattan court as his hush money trial enters its 12th day.\n\nLast week's proceedings saw a frenzy of witnesses take the stand, including former Trump adviser Hope Hicks and Keith Davidson, a lawyer who represented porn actor Stormy Daniels and former Playboy model Karen McDougal in hush money negotiations with Cohen and the National Enquirer.\n\nThe week also saw Trump fined $9,000 by Judge Juan M. Merchan for violating a gag order that bars the former president from speaking publicly about key witnesses, jurors and others in the case. A second contempt hearing was held on Thursday over four more prospective violations, but Merchan did not immediately issue a decision.", "source": {"uri": "lethbridgenewsnow.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8113916676", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "13:56:45", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T13:56:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T13:56:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.brandonsun.com/world/2024/05/06/the-latest-judge-fines-trump-1k-for-contempt-threatens-jail-time-if-he-violates-gag-order-again", "title": "The Latest | Judge fines Trump $1K for contempt, threatens jail time if he violates gag order again", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) -- The judge in Donald Trump's hush money trial sanctioned him Monday morning for violating his gag order for a second time.\n\nJudge Juan M. Merchan fined the former president $1,000 and warned that going forward, additional violations could result in jail time. Prosecutors had accused Trump of four violations, but the judge only concurred with one.\n\nWitness testimony was set to resume following Merchan's ruling, setting the stage for an even deeper dive into the events and people involved in what prosecutors have said was a scheme to influence the 2016 presidential election by buying and burying negative stories about the then-candidate.\n\nThe trial is in its 12th day.\n\nFormer Trump adviser Hope Hicks took the stand last week, recounting how Trump's campaign was turned upside-down following the leak of a video wherein he bragged about grabbing women without their permission.\n\nKeith Davidson, who represented porn actor Stormy Daniels and former Playboy model Karen McDougal in hush money negotiations, also took the stand. Davidson spent hours detailing his role in securing payouts for Daniels and McDougal in exchange for their silence about previous sexual encounters they said they had with Trump.\n\nOverall, prosecutors are setting the stage for pivotal testimony from Michael Cohen, who paid Daniels $130,000 for her silence before he went to prison for the hush money scheme.\n\nTrump is accused of falsifying internal business records to cover up hush money payments -- including the payment to Daniels -- recording them instead as legal expenses.\n\nTrump has pleaded not guilty to 34 felony counts of falsifying business records.\n\nThe case is the first-ever criminal trial of a former U.S. president and the first of four prosecutions of Trump to reach a jury.\n\nCurrently:\n\n-- Hush money, catch and kill and more: Terms to know in Trump trial\n\n-- What Trump's gag order means in his hush money case\n\n-- Key players: Who's who at Donald Trump's hush money criminal trial\n\n-- The hush money case is just one of Trump's legal cases. See the others here\n\n-- Hulk Hogan, hurricanes and a blockbuster recording: A week in the Trump hush money trial\n\nHere's the latest:\n\nJUDGE FINES TRUMP AGAIN FOR CONTEMPT, THREATENS JAIL TIME\n\nThe judge presiding over former President Donald Trump's hush money trial has fined him an additional $1,000 for again violating a gag order barring him from making inflammatory comments about witnesses and jurors.\n\nJudge Juan M. Merchan warned on Monday that additional gag order violations could potentially result in jail time.\n\n\"The last thing I want to do is put you in jail. You are the former president of the United States and possibly the next president as well,\" Merchan said. \"There are many reasons why incarceration is truly a last resort for me. To take that step would be disruptive to these proceedings.\"\n\nTrump sat forward in his seat, glowering at the judge as he handed down the ruling. Once the judge finished speaking, Trump shook his head twice and crossed his arms.\n\nProsecutors had accused Trump of four violations, but the judge only concurred with one.\n\nThe judge had previously fined Trump $9,000 for nine earlier violations in posts on Truth Social and his website.\n\nTRUMP TALKS COLUMBIA COMMENCEMENT CANCELLATION BEFORE COURT\n\nBefore heading into the courtroom Monday morning, Donald Trump spoke to reporters, relaying familiar complaints about the fairness of the trial, the judge and the gag order that stops him commenting on witnesses and jurors.\n\nHe also noted the breaking news that Columbia University canceled its main commencement following weeks of pro-Palestinian protests.\n\nDonald Trump has arrived at the courthouse in lower Manhattan as witness testimony in his hush money trial enters its third week.\n\nWitness testimony in Donald Trump's criminal trial is entering its third week on Monday and it remains to be seen who will take the stand next.\n\nOver the past couple weeks, jurors have heard from a host of different people.\n\nFollowing a weeklong jury selection process that began mid-April, jurors heard first from former National Enquirer publisher David Pecker, who among other things explained his pledge to be the \"eyes and ears\" of Trump's 2016 presidential campaign.\n\nKeith Davidson, a lawyer who represented porn actor Stormy Daniels and former Playboy model Karen McDougal in hush money negotiations, also took the stand. And jurors heard from others such as a forensic analyst who examined Michael Cohen's phones and a paralegal with the Manhattan district attorney's office.\n\nFormer White House press secretary and ex-Trump adviser Hope Hicks on Friday painted a vivid picture of the chaos that unfolded after the \"Access Hollywood\" tape leaked and the Wall Street Journal ran a story about McDougal's hush money deal.\n\nThe defense cross-examined Hicks for roughly 20 minutes before court adjourned early last Friday.\n\nTHE WITNESS HEARD, BUT NOT YET SEEN\n\nAlthough an ensemble of different people have testified in Donald Trump's hush money case over the past two weeks, one pivotal witness has been frequently heard but not yet seen: Michael Cohen, Trump's former lawyer and personal fixer.\n\nJurors last week began hearing Cohen's words on audio recordings as prosecutors worked to directly tie Trump to payments to silence women with damaging claims about him before the 2016 election.\n\nJurors heard, in particular, a potentially crucial piece of evidence: a recording of Trump and Cohen, then his attorney, discussing a plan to pay off an ex-Playboy model who claimed to have an affair with Trump. The former president denies the affair.\n\nThey also heard a few witnesses recount their interactions with Cohen -- some pleasant and others far less so.\n\nIt's unclear when the prosecution's star witness will take the stand.\n\nTRUMP EXPECTED IN COURT AS TRIAL ENTERS 12TH DAY\n\nDonald Trump is expected to return to Manhattan court as his hush money trial enters its 12th day.\n\nLast week's proceedings saw a frenzy of witnesses take the stand, including former Trump adviser Hope Hicks and Keith Davidson, a lawyer who represented porn actor Stormy Daniels and former Playboy model Karen McDougal in hush money negotiations with Cohen and the National Enquirer.\n\nThe week also saw Trump fined $9,000 by Judge Juan M. Merchan for violating a gag order that bars the former president from speaking publicly about key witnesses, jurors and others in the case. A second contempt hearing was held on Thursday over four more prospective violations, but Merchan did not immediately issue a decision.", "source": {"uri": "brandonsun.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8111081036", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "12:23:49", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T12:23:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T12:23:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.thepeterboroughexaminer.com/news/world/united-states/hulk-hogan-hurricanes-and-a-blockbuster-recording-a-week-in-review-of-the-trump-hush/article_8a4a9cf5-6eb6-5d36-80d5-b0fc70b6521b.html", "title": "Hulk Hogan, hurricanes and a blockbuster recording: A week in review of the Trump hush money trial", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Crucial witnesses took the stand in the second week of testimony in Donald Trump's hush money trial, including a California lawyer who negotiated deals at the center of the case and a longtime adviser to the former president.\n\nJurors heard a potentially pivotal piece of evidence -- a 2016 recording of Trump discussing a plan to buy a Playboy model's silence -- as well as testimony about the wrestler Hulk Hogan and hurricanes, literal and figurative.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nOutside the jury's presence, Trump was fined for running afoul of a judge's gag order. Additional sanctions could await the presumptive Republican nominee for president.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nA look at some of the highlights from the past week:\n\nA POLITICAL HURRICANE ... AND AN ACTUAL ONE\n\nHope Hicks, a onetime Trump confidant who for years was central in his orbit, described in detail a seminal moment of the 2016 campaign: The Washington Post's disclosure of a 2005 \"Access Hollywood\" recording in which Trump boasted about grabbing women's genitals without their permission.\n\nHicks acknowledged being \"concerned, very concerned\" when a reporter reached out to her for comment before breaking the story.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"I had a good sense to believe this was going to be a massive story and that it was going to dominate the news cycle for the next several days,\" Hicks testified. \"This was a damaging development.\"\n\nYou might be interested in Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe recording, made public just days before a debate with Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton, is relevant to the case because prosecutors believe it helps explain the frenetic efforts by Trump and allies in the campaign's remaining weeks to try to suppress any additional harmful stories that might arise.\n\nIn fact, in the aftermath of the tape's release, Hicks said she asked Michael Cohen, Trump's then-lawyer and personal fixer, to hunt down a rumor of another potentially damaging recording. \"There was no such tape regardless,\" Hicks said, \"but he sort of chased that down for me.\"\n\nRegardless, the immediate impact of the \"Access Hollywood\" story was so intense, Hicks recalled, that it took attention away from an actual storm. Hurricane Matthew was dominating the news cycle when Hicks was contacted about the forthcoming story. That didn't last long.\n\n\"The 'Access Hollywood' tape pushed the hurricane off the news?\" prosecutor Matthew Colangelo asked.\n\n\"Yes,\" Hicks replied.\n\nTRUMP THE EXTORTION TARGET?\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nTrump may be a criminal defendant, but an element of his defense came into view this past week when one of his lawyers suggested Trump might actually have been a victim.\n\nAttorney Emil Bove implied during a notably tense cross-examination that his client had been effectively targeted for extortion by Keith Davidson, a crucial witness and the lawyer who negotiated hush money deals for two women, porn actor Stormy Daniels and Playboy model Karen McDougal, claiming to have had sexual encounters with Trump. Trump denies it.\n\nBove name-dropped a gaggle of celebrities he suggested had been coerced over the years into paying Davidson's clients eye-popping sums to suppress harmful videos or stories. Among them was actor Charlie Sheen, whom Bove said Davidson had \"extracted sums of money from;\" Davidson took issue with the word \"extract\" but said he had been involved in \"valid settlements\" with Sheen.\n\nDavidson also acknowledge that he had faced an FBI investigation, but was never charged, for allegedly attempting to extort Hogan to head off the release of the professional wrestling star's sex tape.\n\nBy 2016, Bove suggested, Davidson was well-versed in the concept of squeezing celebrities such as Trump.\n\n\"And you did everything that you could to get as close to that line as possible in these negotiations without crossing it, right?\" Bove asked.\n\n\"I did everything I could to make sure my activities were lawful,\" Davidson replied.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n'WHAT DO WE GOT TO PAY FOR THIS?'\n\nThe prosecution's key witness, Cohen, has yet to testify -- and Trump might never at all -- but their voices were played in the courtroom in perhaps the most vivid piece of evidence so far.\n\nProsecutors played aloud a September 2016 recording that Cohen made of himself briefing the then-presidential candidate on a plan to buy McDougal's silence with a $150,000 payment. McDougal was prepared to come forward with her account of an extramarital affair with Trump, a disclosure Trump and his allies were determined to prevent in the final days of the election.\n\n\"What do we got to pay for this? One-fifty?\" Trump can be heard saying at one point.\n\nThey discuss whether the payment should be done with cash or check. Then the recording cuts out.\n\nThough the existence of the recording surfaced in the summer of 2018 and has long been known to the public, its disclosure to the jury was a dramatic moment meant to establish that the hush money payment was done with Trump's knowledge.\n\nHe appeared visibly irritated as the recording was played. Jurors seemed riveted.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nTHE 'JERK'\n\nThe recording was hardly the only time Cohen surfaced in court over the past week. When he did, it was generally in a negative light.\n\nDavidson said his introduction to Cohen came in 2011 when Davidson was told that he needed to return an angry call from Cohen over a blog post related to Daniels and Trump. Davidson said Cohen was described to him by Daniels' talent manager as \"some jerk\" who have been \"very, very aggressive and threatened to sue me.\"\n\nWhen Davidson called Cohen and introduced himself, \"I was just met with, like, a hustle barrage of insults and insinuations and allegations. That went on for quite a while.\"\n\nDavidson also recounted a memorable phone conversation with Cohen one month after the 2016 election in which the Trump attorney sounded \"depressed and despondent\" and complained about being passed over for a role in the new Trump administration.\n\n\"He said something to the effect of: 'Jesus Christ. Can you (expletive) believe I'm not going to Washington,'\" Davidson described Cohen as saying. \"'After everything I've done for that (expletive) guy. I can't believe I'm not going to Washington. I've saved that guy's (expletive) so many times, you don't even know.'\"\n\nThe uncharitable characterizations may help Trump's team in its efforts to undermine Cohen's credibility. But they could also help prosecutors distance themselves from Cohen, subtly indicating to jurors that he is not a teammate but rather someone who simply has information.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nTO JAIL A PRESIDENT\n\nA side issue throughout the trial is what to do about Trump's outside-of-court comments. He repeatedly has maligned witnesses and suggested bias on the jury -- all despite a judge's gag order meant to bar him from verbal tirades against key players in the case.\n\nTrump was assessed a $9,000 fine -- $1,000 for each of nine separate gag order violations that the judge identified. Prosecutors later requested an additional $4,000 penalty for what they said were additional breaches of the order.\n\nYet it remains unclear what, if anything, Judge Juan M. Merchan can do in the event of continued violations. Merchan floated the possibility of jail, an unprecedented outcome for a former American president. That also would risk inflaming Trump's base as he pursues the presidency and would further upend the 2024 White House race.\n\nTrump's attorneys insist he needs some leeway to be able to respond to relentless criticism, including from witnesses, and that his candidacy means he's the subject of nonstop news media coverage.\n\nMerchan seemed unpersuaded, but jail, for now at least, seems to be no one's desired outcome.\n\n\"Because each of these statements was made before the Court held the Defendant in contempt for violating this order nine previous times, and because we prefer to minimize disruptions to this proceeding, we are not yet seeking jail,\" prosecutor Chris Conroy said.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"But,\" he added, \"the Court's decision this past Tuesday will inform the approach we take to any future violations.\"", "source": {"uri": "thepeterboroughexaminer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "thepeterboroughexaminer.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8113715025", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "11:45:18", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T11:45:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T11:44:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.inquirer.com/politics/nation/donald-trump-hush-money-trial-stormy-daniels-hope-hicks-20240506.html", "title": "Prosecutors move deeper into Donald Trump's orbit as testimony in hush money trial enters a third week", "body": "NEW YORK -- Prosecutors in Donald Trump's hush money trial are moving deeper into his orbit following an inside-the-room account about the former president's reaction to a politically damaging recording that surfaced in the final weeks of the 2016 campaign.\n\nHope Hicks, a former White House official and for years a top aide, is by far the closest Trump associate to have taken the witness stand in the Manhattan trial.\n\n\" READ MORE: Hope Hicks, ex-Trump adviser, recounts fear in 2016 campaign over impact of 'Access Hollywood' tape\n\nHer testimony Friday was designed to give jurors an insider's view of a chaotic and pivotal stretch in the campaign, when a 2005 recording showing Trump talking about grabbing women without their permission was made public and when he and his allies sought to prevent the release of other potentially embarrassing stories. That effort, prosecutors say, included hush money payments to a porn actor and Playboy model who both have said they had sexual encounters with Trump before he entered politics.\n\n\"I had a good sense to believe this was going to be a massive story and that it was going to dominate the news cycle for the next several days,\" Hicks said of the \"Access Hollywood\" recording, first revealed in an October 2016 Washington Post story. \"This was a damaging development.\"\n\nThe trial enters its third week of testimony Monday with prosecutors building toward their star witness, Michael Cohen, Trump's former lawyer and personal fixer who pleaded guilty to federal charges related to the hush money payments. Cohen is expected to undergo a bruising cross-examination from defense attorneys seeking to undermine his credibility with jurors.\n\nTrump faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records in connection with payments made to stifle potentially embarrassing stories. Prosecutors say Trump's company, the Trump Organization, reimbursed Cohen for payments to porn actor Stormy Daniels and gave Cohen bonuses and extra payments. Prosecutors allege that those transactions were falsely logged in company records as legal expenses.\n\nTrump has pleaded not guilty and denied sexual encounters with any of the women, as well as any wrongdoing.\n\nSo far, jurors have heard from witnesses including a tabloid magazine publisher and Trump friend who bought the rights to several sordid tales about Trump to prevent them from coming out and a Los Angeles lawyer who negotiated hush money deals on behalf of both Daniels and Playboy model Karen McDougal.\n\nTrump's lawyers have tried to chip away at the prosecution's theory of the case and the credibility of some witnesses. They've raised questions during cross-examinations about whether Trump was possibly a target of extortion, forced to arrange payouts to suppress harmful stories and spare his family embarrassment and pain. Prosecutors maintain the payments were about preserving his political viability as he sought the presidency.\n\nThe case is one of four Trump prosecutions and possibly the only one that will reach trial before the November election. Other felony indictments charge him with plotting to subvert the 2020 presidential election after he lost to Democrat Joe Biden and illegally hoarding classified documents after he left the White House.", "source": {"uri": "inquirer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Philadelphia Inquirer"}, "authors": [{"uri": "eric_tucker@inquirer.com", "name": "Eric Tucker", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "jennifer_peltz@inquirer.com", "name": "Jennifer Peltz", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "michael_r_sisak@inquirer.com", "name": "Michael R.
